{{Infobox convention | name = Seacon '79, the 37th World Science Fiction Convention | image = | caption = | status = | genre = [[Science fiction]] | venue = [[Hilton Brighton Metropole|Metropole Hotel]] | location = [[Brighton]] | country = United Kingdom | first = 23–26 August 1979 | organizer = | filing = | attendance = 3,114 | website = }} The '''37th World Science Fiction Convention''' ([[Worldcon]]) was '''Seacon '79''', which was held in [[Brighton]], United Kingdom, 23–26 August 1979 at the [[Hilton Brighton Metropole|Metropole Hotel]].{{cite web |work=Time Out of Mind |title=World Science Fiction Convention |publisher=[[BBC Two]] |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jMga-1TVZWc |date=1979 |accessdate=August 21, 2014}} The Guests of Honour of the 37th Worldcon were [[Brian Aldiss]] (UK), [[Fritz Leiber]] (U.S.), and Harry Bell (fan). The convention committee was chaired by [[Peter Weston]]. The toastmaster was [[Bob Shaw]]. There were 3,114 registered members of the convention who attended. == Awards == {{About-Hugos}} ===Hugo Awards=== * [[Hugo Award for Best Novel|Best Novel]]: ''[[Dreamsnake]]'' by [[Vonda McIntyre]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Novella|Best Novella]]: "[[The Persistence of Vision (short story)|The Persistence of Vision]]" by [[John Varley (author)|John Varley]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Novelette|Best Novelette]]: "[[Hunter's Moon (novelette)|Hunter's Moon]]" by [[Poul Anderson]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Short Story|Best Short Story]]: "[[Cassandra (story)|Cassandra]]" by [[C. J. Geis]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Fan Writer|Best Fan Writer]]: [[Bob Shaw]] * [[Hugo Award for Best Fan Artist|Best Fan Artist]]: [[William Rotsler|Bill Rotsler]] ===Other awards=== * [[John W. {{unreferenced|date=February 2016}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2011}} {{Year nav|-492}} {{BC year in topic|492}} __NOTOC__ Year '''492 BC''' was a year of the [[Roman calendar|pre-Julian Roman calendar]]. At the time, it was known as the '''Year of the Consulship of Macerinus and Augurinus''' (or, less frequently, '''year 262 ''[[Ab urbe condita]]'''''). The denomination 492 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the [[Anno Domini]] [[calendar era]] became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.
== Events == <onlyinclude>
=== By place === ==== Greece ==== * The first expedition of King [[Darius I]] of [[Persia]] against [[Ancient Greece|Greece]] commences under the leadership of his son-in-law and general, [[Mardonius (general)|Mardonius]]. Darius sends Mardonius to succeed his [[satrap]] (governor) in [[Ionia]], [[Artaphernes]], with a special commission to attack [[Athens]] and [[Eretria]]. * The Persians under Mardonius subdue and capture [[Thrace]] and [[Macedon]]ia. * Mardonius loses some 300 ships in a storm off [[Mount Athos]], which forces him to abandon his plans to attack Athens and Eretria.
==== Sicily ==== * When [[Kamarina, Sicily|Camarina]], a Syracusan colony, rebels, [[Hippocrates of Gela|Hippocrates]], the [[tyrant]] of [[Gela]], intervenes to wage war against [[Syracuse, Sicily|Syracuse]]. After defeating the Syracusan army at the [[Heloros River]], he besieges the city. However, he is persuaded by the intervention of forces from the Greek mainland city of [[Corinth]] to retreat in exchange for the possession of Camarina.
==== Rome ==== * Following the conclusion of the [[First secessio plebis in 494 BC|secession of the plebs]], a famine strikes Rome. The consuls avert the crisis by obtaining grain from [[Etruria]]. * War with the [[Volsci]] is [[Roman-Volscian_wars#Hostilities_averted_in_492_BC|averted]] because a pestilence affects the Volsci. Rome sends additional colonists to [[Velitrae]] and establishes a new [[Roman colony|colony]] in [[Norba]].
</onlyinclude>

[[Sonia Mankaï]] | music = [[Jean-Marie Sénia]] | cinematography = | editing = | distributor = Les Films du Losange | released = {{film date|1996}} | runtime = 89 minutes | country = France, Belgium, Tunisia | language = [[French language|French]], [[Arabic language|Arabic]], [[Italian language|Italian]] | budget = }} '''''A Summer in La Goulette''''' ({{lang-fr|Un été à La Goulette}}, {{lang-ar|صيف حلق الوادي}}) is a 1996 film by [[Tunisia]]n director [[Férid Boughedir]]. It is a narrative of how intercommunal relations deteriorated in cosmopolitan [[La Goulette]] after the end of [[History of French-era Tunisia|French rule]], especially [[Muslim]]-[[Jewish]] relations affected by [[Six-Day War]] and the rising impact of [[Islam]] on the Tunisian society. The film also features La Goulette native [[Claudia Cardinale]] as herself. The film was entered into the [[46th Berlin International Film Festival]].{{cite web |url=http://www.berlinale.de/en/archiv/jahresarchive/1996/02_programm_1996/02_Programm_1996.html |title=Berlinale: 1996 Programme |accessdate=2012-01-01 |work=berlinale.de}} == Plot == Youssef ([[Mustapha Adouani]]) is a Muslim who works on the [[TGM]] and lives in La Goulette. His best friends are [[Tunisian Jews|Jewish]] Jojo the [[brik]] seller and [[Italian Tunisians|Sicilian]] [[Catholic]] Giuseppe the fisherman who are also his neighbours. Their daughters grow up together and share prospects for life but the landlord [[Hajji|Hadj]] Beji ([[Gamil Ratib]]) has his eyes on Youssef's daughter Meriem ([[Sonia Mankaï]]). ==Cast== * Gamil Ratib : Hadj Beji * Mustapha Adouani : Youssef * [[Guy Nataf]] : Jojo * [[Ivo Salerno]] : Giuseppe * [[Michel Boujenah]] : TSF * [[Claudia Cardinale]] : herself * Sonia Mankaï : Meriem * [[Ava Cohen-Jonathan]] : Tina * [[Sarah Pariente]] : Gigi * [[Kais Ben Messaoud]] : Chouchou * [[Mohamed Driss]] : Miró == See also == *''[[Le Chant des mariées]]'' ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0114775|title=Un été à La Goulette}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Summer In La Goulette}} [[Category:1996 films]] [[Category:1990s drama films]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:French drama films]] [[Category:Tunisian films]] [[Category:Belgian films]] [[Category:French-language films]] [[Category:Arabic-language films]] [[Category:Italian-language films]] [[Category:Films about race and ethnicity]] [[Category:Coming-of-age films]] [[Category:Films set in Tunisia]] [[Category:Films set in 1967]] [[Category:Films directed by Férid Boughedir]] [[Category:Works about the Six-Day War]] {{Tunisia-film-stub}}

The '''American Kitefliers Association''' ('''AKA''') was created in 1964 by Robert M. Ingraham of [[New Mexico]]. Its purpose is to educate the public in the art, history, technology, and practice of building and flying [[kite]]s and advance the joys and values of kiting in all nations. AKA is the largest association of kiters with over 3,000 members in 25 countries. There are conventions held annually for all club members each year at different venues around the country.
The American Kitefliers Association also regulates competitions and other showy kite events all over the country. Fliers of precision [[stunt kite]]s, which can make 90-degree turns and do tricks, are judged on how well they conform to prescribed flight patterns with many twists and turns.<ref>CONSIDINE, A. (2006). Ahead | kite festivals; air wars, with paper and string. New York Times, 2-1</ref>

{{Infobox motorsport championship | logo = | pixels = | caption = | category = [[One-Design|One-make racing]] by [[Aston Martin]] | inaugural = 2007 | cars = | constructors = [[Aston Martin]] | tyres = [[Michelin]] | engines = | country/region = [[Asia]] | folded = 2009 | current_season = | website = }} [[Image:2008 Keiko Ihara AMAC.jpg|right|thumb|250px|The Aston Martin V8 Vantage of [[Keiko Ihara]] at Zhuhai International Circuit, waiting to race in the Aston Martin Asia Cup race.]]
The '''Aston Martin Asia Cup''' (AMAC) is the world's first ever [[Aston Martin]] one make series. All drivers will compete for the AMAC title in identical [[Aston Martin V8 Vantage (2005)|Aston Martin V8 Vantage]] N24 race cars.
The series started in 2008 and consisted of 10 races throughout the Asia Pacific region including China, Japan, Malaysia and Singapore. Each race features a grid of 15 Aston Martin Vantage N24s, a 4.3 litre race-developed evolution of the V8 Vantage.
The AMAC includes a variety of 30-minute sprint races and longer endurance races, some of which support Formula One events in the region, like the [[Singapore Grand Prix]] and the [[Chinese Grand Prix]].
==Race Car== The V8 Vantage has a V8 engine producing 410 bhp and weighs just 1350 kg. The 18 AMAC cars have the automated manual Sportshift transmission, and all the cars are equipped with roll cages, safety fuel tanks, race seats and harnesses, and fire extinguisher systems. The cars will be serviced at the Aston Martin Beijing service facility at the city's Goldenport race circuit.<ref>[http://www.astonmartinracing.com/eng/news?a=02df19a0-f937-459b-837d-12d13e71a501 New Aston Martin race series for Asia in 2008]</ref> [[Michelin]] is the sole tyre supplier.<ref>[http://www.astonmartin-asiacup.com/index.html Aston Martin Asia Cup Introduction] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081208031955/http://www.astonmartin-asiacup.com/index.html |date=8 December 2008 }}</ref>
==Prize== The Championship offers a fully sponsored season in a Vantage N24 in the 2009 FIA [[GT4 European Cup|GT4]] Championship for the winner.
==Circuits visited== The inaugural season in 2008 had 10 rounds, and saw the series visit the following circuits:
* [[Shanghai International Circuit]], China * [[Sepang International Circuit]], Malaysia * [[Singapore Street Circuit]], Singapore * [[Zhuhai International Circuit]], China
==Series champions== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" !colspan="6" align="center"|Aston Martin Asia Cup Champions |- !Year !Driver !Car |- |2008 |{{flagicon|Japan}} [[Kota Sasaki]]<ref>[http://www.astonmartinracing.com/news?a=7e980eb6-ddb7-450f-bd63-c358ac4239eb Kota Sasaki becomes 2008 Aston Martin Asia Cup Champion]</ref> |[[Aston Martin V8 Vantage (2005)|Aston Martin V8 Vantage]] |- |}

{{short description|Final public speech of Barack Obama as US President}} {{use mdy dates|date=January 2017}} [[File:20170110_President_Obama_Farewell_Speech_HD.webm|right|thumb|320px|[[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]] delivers his [[farewell address]] to the nation in Chicago.]] {{wikisource|Barack Obama's Farewell Address}} '''Barack Obama's farewell address''' was the [[s:Barack Obama's Farewell Address|final public speech]] of [[Barack Obama]] as the 44th President of the United States, delivered on January 10, 2017 at 9:00 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|EST]].<ref name="whitehousefarewell">{{cite web|title=President Obama's Farewell Address|url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/farewell|website=The White House|accessdate=21 January 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref name="whfarewell">{{Cite web|url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/farewell/info|title=Farewell Address logistics|website=The White House|language=en|access-date=2017-01-23}}</ref> The farewell address was broadcast on various television and radio stations and livestreamed online by the White House. An estimated 24 million people watched the address live on television.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Huddleston, Jr.|first1=Tom|title=Here's How Many People Tuned In to Watch Obama's Farewell Address|url=http://fortune.com/2017/01/11/obama-farewell-address-tv-ratings/|accessdate=21 January 2017|work=Fortune|date=11 January 2017}}</ref> The speech and its transcript are available on the archived version of the Obama Whitehouse website.<ref name="whitehousefarewell"/>
==Background== {{main|Presidency of Barack Obama}} Obama served as the first [[African American]] [[President of the United States]] for two terms, first elected in [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008]] and reelected in [[United States presidential election, 2012|2012]]. During his presidency, his administration addressed the [[Financial crisis of 2007–08|2007-2008 global financial crisis]] (including a [[American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009|major stimulus package]]), oversaw the passage and implementation of the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]], partially extended [[Bush tax cuts]], took [[Immigration reform#Obama's executive actions of November 2014|executive action]] on immigration reform, and took [[Clean Power Plan|steps]] to combat [[climate change]] and [[greenhouse gas|carbon emissions]]. Obama also authorized the [[Death of Osama bin Laden|raid]] that killed Osama bin Laden, signed the [[New START]] treaty with [[Russia]], signed the [[Paris Agreement]], and negotiated rapprochements with [[Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action|Iran]] and [[Cuban Thaw|Cuba]]. Democrats controlled both houses of Congress until Republicans won a majority in the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] in the [[United States elections, 2010|2010 elections]]. Republicans took control of the [[United States Senate|Senate]] after the [[United States elections, 2014|2014 elections]], and Obama continued to grapple with Congressional Republicans over government spending, [[Deferred Action for Parents of Americans|immigration]], [[Merrick Garland Supreme Court nomination|judicial nominations]], and other issues.
In the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]], Obama was ineligible to seek reelection to a third term due to the restrictions of the [[Twenty-second Amendment to the United States Constitution|Twenty-second Amendment]]. In June 2016, Obama endorsed his former [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]], [[Hillary Clinton]], to succeed him as president.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Davis|first1=Julie Hirschfeld|last2=Martin|first2=Jonathan|title=Obama Endorses Hillary Clinton, and Urges Democrats to Unite|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/10/us/politics/obama-hillary-clinton-endorsement.html|accessdate=21 January 2017|work=The New York Times|date=9 June 2016}}</ref> He addressed the [[2016 Democratic National Convention]] on July 27 in support of Clinton as the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party's]] [[Democratic Party presidential primaries, 2016|nominee]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Liptak|first1=Kevin|title=Barack Obama slams Trump, makes appeal for Hillary Clinton|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/07/27/politics/president-obama-democratic-convention-speech/|accessdate=21 January 2017|work=CNN|date=28 July 2016}}</ref> and continued to campaign for her throughout the 2016 general election campaign season.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Phelps|first1=Jordyn|title=Obama's Final Big Role as President: Campaigner in Chief|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/president-obamas-campaign-blitz-hillary-clinton-historic/story?id=43249593|accessdate=21 January 2017|work=ABC News|date=2 November 2016}}</ref> However, Hillary Clinton would unexpectedly lose the general election to [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] nominee [[Donald Trump]] on November 8, after failing to receive enough votes in the [[Electoral College (United States)|Electoral College]], despite receiving a plurality of the national popular vote. The Democratic Party would no longer control the presidency once Trump was [[United States presidential inauguration|inaugurated]] on January 20, 2017, and they did not have a majority of seats in either chamber of the [[United States Congress]], and in the state legislatures and governorships. President Obama's approval ratings were nearly at 60 percent at the time of his farewell speech.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dovere|first1=Edward-Isaac|title=Democrats in the Wilderness|url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2017/01/democrats-trump-administration-wilderness-comeback-revival-214650|accessdate=21 January 2017|work=POLITICO Magazine}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Edelman|first1=Adam|title=President Obama's final approval rating is 60%, poll shows|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/president-obama-final-approval-rating-60-poll-shows-article-1.2949260|accessdate=22 January 2017|work=NY Daily News|date=18 January 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Tani|first1=Maxwell|title=Obama's approval rating soars as he exits the White House|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/obamas-approval-rating-final-2017-1|accessdate=22 January 2017|work=Business Insider|date=19 January 2017|language=en}}</ref>
==Venue== In a break with recent tradition, President Obama did not deliver his farewell address at the [[White House]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Flood|first1=Rebecca|title=President Barack Obama breaks tradition to deliver farewell speech in home-town|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/world/752632/president-Barack-Obama-speech-farewell-Trump-Chicago-tradition|accessdate=21 January 2017|work=Express|date=10 January 2017|language=en}}</ref> Instead, he gave the speech at the [[McCormick Place]] convention center in his home city of [[Chicago]], less than four miles from [[Grant Park (Chicago)|Grant Park]], where he delivered his [[Barack Obama election victory speech, 2008|2008 election victory speech]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Korte|first1=Gregory|title=Obama's farewell speech: Here's what to expect|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2017/01/10/what-time-is-obama-farewell-speech/96372452/|accessdate=21 January 2017|work=USA TODAY|date=10 January 2017|language=en}}</ref> McCormick Place is also the same venue where Obama delivered his [[s:Barack Obama's 2012 election victory speech|2012 reelection victory speech]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Kristen|title=President Obama gives victory speech: 'Never been more hopeful about America'|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/president-obama-victory-speech-hopeful-america-article-1.1197895|accessdate=22 January 2017|work=NY Daily News|date=7 November 2012|language=en}}</ref>
The event was open to the public, with free tickets being distributed on a first-come, first-served basis on January 7.<ref name="whfarewell" />
==Writing the address== [[File:PeteSouzaWHPhotoKeenanFarewellSpeechAirForceOne.png|thumb|200x200px|Keenan checks Obama's farewell address one last time aboard Air Force One en route to Chicago]] On January 2, 2017, President Obama released a post on the White House blog publicly announcing that he would deliver his farewell address in his hometown of Chicago, and stated that he was "just beginning" to write his remarks and that he was "thinking about them as a chance to say thank you for this amazing journey, to celebrate the ways you've changed this country for the better these past eight years, and to offer some thoughts on where we all go from here."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Obama|first1=Barack|title=My Farewell Address|url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/blog/2017/01/02/my-farewell-address|website=whitehouse.gov|accessdate=22 January 2017|language=en|date=2 January 2017}}</ref>
In the January 6th press briefing, [[White House Press Secretary]] [[Josh Earnest]] said that "the President is interested in delivering a farewell address that's forward-looking"<ref>{{cite news|last1=Korte|first1=Gregory|title=Obama's farewell address will be 'forward-looking,' optimistic|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2017/01/07/obamas-farewell-address-forward-looking-optimistic/96272082/|accessdate=22 January 2017|work=USA TODAY|date=7 January 2017|language=en}}</ref> and on January 9 he stated that "there's still a lot of work that needs to be done on the speech. So the President will be doing a lot of thinking between now and then, between now and 9:00 p.m. Eastern tomorrow, thinking about what he wants to say and what sort of presentation he wants to make to the American public as he enters the last couple of weeks that he has here at the White House."<ref>{{cite web|title=Press Briefing by Press Secretary Josh Earnest, 1/9/17|url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/the-press-office/2017/01/09/press-briefing-press-secretary-josh-earnest-1917|website=whitehouse.gov|accessdate=22 January 2017|language=en|date=9 January 2017}}</ref>
The farewell address was written by President Obama, who dictated passages to [[Cody Keenan]], the White House Director of Speechwriting. The President and Keenan went through at least four drafts of the speech. Former White House speechwriter [[Jon Favreau (speechwriter)|Jon Favreau]] and former [[Senior Advisor to the President of the United States|senior advisor]] [[David Axelrod (political consultant)|David Axelrod]] also contributed to the drafting process.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Liptak|first1=Kevin|title=Obama offers optimism -- and warnings -- in farewell address|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/10/politics/obama-farewell-address/|accessdate=22 January 2017|work=CNN}}</ref>
==Summary of the address== [[File:BarackObamaFarewellAddresstotheAmericanPeople13m51s.png|right|thumb|250px|Obama delivers the address]] {{empty section|date=August 2017}}

[[Battery (crime)|Sexual battery]] | motive = | sentence =[[Death penalty|Death]] | imprisoned=[[Union Correctional Institution]] }} '''Bobby Joe Long''' (born October 14, 1953), also known as '''Robert Joe Long''' and '''Robert Joseph Long''', is an American [[serial killer]] and [[rapist]].{{cite web |url=http://www.dc.state.fl.us/offenderSearch/detail.aspx?Page=Detail&DCNumber=494041&TypeSearch=AI |title=Inmate Population Information Detail - Inmate 494041 |publisher=''[[Florida Department of Corrections]]'' |accessdate=2018-11-10 }} Long [[kidnapping|abducted]], [[sexually assaulted]], and [[murder]]ed at least 10 women in the [[Tampa Bay Area]] in Florida during an eight-month period in 1984. He released his last victim, Lisa McVey, after raping her for a period of 26 hours. McVey provided information to the police that enabled them to track him down. Long is currently serving a prison sentence consisting of 28 life sentences, 4 sentences of 99 years and the death sentence in the United States. {{cite book | first=Eric W. | last=Hickey | year= 1991 | title= Serial Murderers and Their Victims | edition= | publisher=Brooks/Cole | location=Pacific Grove, CA | pages= 135–136 | isbn= 0-534-15414-X }} ==Early life== Long was born on October 14, 1953 in [[Kenova, West Virginia]] to Joe and Louetta Long. He was born with an [[Klinefelter's syndrome|extra X chromosome]], because of which he [[gynaecomastia|grew breasts during puberty]], for which he was severely teased.{{cite web |title=Bobby Joe Long - The Classified Ad Rapist |url=http://maamodt.asp.radford.edu/Long,%20Bobby%20Joe.htm |accessdate=August 12, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821131048/http://maamodt.asp.radford.edu/Long%2C%20Bobby%20Joe.htm |archivedate=August 21, 2008 |publisher=Department of Psychology, [[Radford University]] }} He also suffered multiple head injuries as a child.Giannangelo, Stephen. [https://books.google.com/books?id=rPLpWHyrM-MC&pg=PA22&lpg=PA22&dq=Bobby+Joe+Long+head+injuries&source=bl&ots=be2K9_kdMT&sig=9NBFD6RBjXgDlEpjvusbY3oOR2g&hl=en&ei=YE-DSoH6CtXFmQf1o4CjDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10#v=onepage&q=Bobby%20Joe%20Long%20head%20injuries&f=false ''The Psychopathology of Serial Murder: A Theory of Violence''.] He had a [[dysfunctional family|dysfunctional]] relationship with his mother; he slept in her bed until he was a teenager, and resented her multiple short-term boyfriends. He married his high school girlfriend in 1974, with whom he had two children before she filed for [[divorce]] in 1980.{{cite web |last1=Moore |first1=Melissa |title=Married to a Monster: Ex-wife discusses serial killer who raped, killed 10 women |url=https://crimewatchdaily.com/2016/02/22/ex-wife-offers-look-inside-the-mind-of-notorious-serial-killer/ |website=crimewatch |publisher=Telepictures Productions Inc. |accessdate=8 July 2018 |language=en}} Prior to the Tampa Bay area murders, Long had committed at least 50 [[rape]]s as the "Classified Ad Rapist" in [[Fort Lauderdale]], [[Ocala]], [[Miami]] and [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Dade County]]. Starting in 1981, Long answered [[classified ad]]s for small appliances, and if he found a woman alone at home, he would rape her. He was tried and convicted for rape in 1981 but requested a new trial, which was granted. The charges were later dropped. Before Long killed in Florida, he lived in [[Long Beach, California]], on the 2500 Block of Eucalyptus Avenue, where he rented a room from a woman named Kathy. He dated a 17-year-old girl across the street from his rented room. Long began contacting women through the ''[[Pennysaver|Penny Saver]]'' and other classified ads and when he found a woman alone, he asked to use the bathroom, took out his "rape kit" and brutally raped and robbed the woman. These crimes were never prosecuted by the local California authorities.{{cite book | first=Joel | last=Norris | year= 1988 | title= Serial Killers | edition= | publisher=Doubleday | location=N.Y. | pages= 137–149 | isbn= 0-385-26328-7}}{{cite web | title = Bobby Joe Long: The Classified Ad Rapist | work = Frances Farmers Revenge.com | url = http://www.francesfarmersrevenge.com/stuff/serialkillers/long.htm | accessdate = 1 November 2007 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080105062445/http://www.francesfarmersrevenge.com/stuff/serialkillers/long.htm | archivedate = 5 January 2008 | df = }}{{Unreliable source?|date=April 2013}} ==Murders== Long moved to the Tampa area in 1983. [[Hillsborough County, Florida|Hillsborough County]] had been averaging about 30 to 35 homicides per year in the 1980s. Then, in 1984, the murder rate escalated. During one eight-month period, a killer with a unique method of binding, raping, and killing his victims, then dumping them in unusual positions and poses, was averaging a murder every other week. The first victim was discovered in May 1984, when the [[Hillsborough County Sheriff's Office (Florida)|Hillsborough County Sheriff's Office]] (HCSO) was called to a crime scene where the body of a nude woman had been found.{{cite web |year= |month= |url=http://www.omicidiseriali.it/cases.htm |title=The "Bobby Joe" Long Serial Murder Case: A Study in Cooperation |publisher= |accessdate=2007-11-01 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070807194430/http://www.omicidiseriali.it/cases.htm |archivedate=2007-08-07 |deadurl=yes |df= }} This began an intensive investigation into the abduction, rape, and murder of at least 10 women in three counties in the Tampa Bay area (Hillsborough, [[Pasco County, Florida|Pasco]], [[Pinellas County, Florida|Pinellas]]) involving the personnel from the HCSO, the [[FBI]], the Tampa Police Department (TPD), the Pasco County Sheriff's Office (PCSO), and the Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE). The bodies were found usually long after the murder in a state of decomposition, dumped near a rural roadside and dragged into the woods. ===''Modus operandi''=== In 1984, while on [[probation]] for [[assault]], Long began driving around, trawling for victims in areas known for [[prostitution]] and in bars where women were found alone. He claimed his victims approached him, after which he persuaded them to enter his car and took them to an apartment. There he bound his victims with rope and [[Strangling|ligature collar]]s he fashioned using a variety of rope knots, later confessing that he derived [[Sadomasochism|sadistic]] pleasure from the abduction, rape, and brutal murder of his victims. Some he strangled, others he killed by slitting their throats or bludgeoning. The bodies were placed in unique positions or "displayed," for example with their legs splayed five feet apart at odd angles. Of Long's ten known victims, five were identified as sex workers, two as [[exotic dancers]], one was a factory worker, one was a student, and one was of unknown occupation. ==Capture== At the time of his capture, Long was wanted in three Tampa Bay area jurisdictions where investigators had collected [[forensic evidence]], including clothing and carpet fibers, [[semen]], ligature marks, and rope knots. Long was arrested on November 16, 1984, and charged with the [[sexual battery]] and kidnapping of Lisa McVey. Long signed a formal [[Miranda warning|Miranda]] waiver, and consented to questioning. After the detectives procured a confession for the McVey case, their questioning focused on a series of unsolved sexual battery homicides pending in the area. As the detectives began to question Long about the murders, he replied, "I'd rather not answer that." The detectives continued the interrogation, and handed Long photographs of the various murder victims. At this point, Long stated, "The complexion of things sure have changed since you came back into the room. I think I might need an attorney." No attorney was provided, and Long eventually confessed to eight murders in Hillsborough County, and one murder in Pasco County.{{cite web |date=June 30, 1988 |url=http://www.oranous.com/florida/RobertLong/063088long.html |title=ROBERT JOE LONG, a/k/a v. STATE OF FLORIDA, |publisher= |accessdate=2007-11-01 }}{{cite web | last =Ramsland | first =Katherine | title =Bobby Joe Long | work =Crime Library | publisher =truTV | date = | url =http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/predators/long/6.html | accessdate = 30 April 2013}} [[Fiber]] evidence analysis by the FBI linked Long's vehicle to most of his victims. ==Trial== The Hillsborough County State Attorney's Office confronted Long with the evidence. The State Attorney and the Public Defender's Office of Hillsborough County reached a [[plea bargain]] for eight of the homicides and the abduction and rape of Lisa McVey. Long pled guilty on September 24, 1985, to all of these crimes, receiving 26 [[life sentence]]s without the possibility of [[parole]] (24 concurrent and two to run consecutively to the first 24) and seven life sentences with the possibility of parole after 25 years. In addition, the State retained the option to seek the [[death penalty]] for the murder of Michelle Simms. In July 1986, the [[penalty phase]] of the Michelle Simms trial was held in Tampa. It lasted one week and again received extensive media attention. Long was found guilty and was sentenced to die in Florida's [[electric chair]]. Although Long confessed to raping and killing women, his confession was thrown out. His trial proceeded straight to the penalty phase, which was possible in the 1980s. In early 1985, he received the death penalty. Long was convicted and [[appeal]]ed his first degree murder conviction and death sentence for crimes committed in Hillsborough County.{{cite web |date=June 30, 1988 |url=http://www.oranous.com/florida/RobertLong/063088long.html |title=ROBERT JOE LONG, a/k/a BOBBY LONG, Appellant, v. STATE OF FLORIDA, Appellee No. 69,259 |publisher= |accessdate=2007-11-01 }} Long appealed his first degree murder conviction and sentence of death in the death of Virginia Johnson.{{cite web |date=November 12, 1987 |url=http://www.oranous.com/florida/RobertLong/111287long.html |title=Robert Joe Long, Appellant, v. State of Florida, Appellee |publisher= |accessdate=2007-11-01 }} On appeal from the Circuit Court in and for Pasco County, in which Long's death sentence was vacated, his conviction reversed, and his case remanded to the trial court with directions to enter an order of [[acquittal]] for the murder of Virginia Johnson.{{cite web |date=March 6, 1997 |url=http://www.oranous.com/florida/RobertLong/Robert%20J.%20Long%20v.%20State%20Of%20Florida.htm |title=ROBERT J. LONG, Appellant, vs. State of Florida, Appellee, No. 83,593 Corrected Opinion |publisher= |accessdate=2007-11-01 }} On February 24, 1999, Long accused the Capital Collateral Regional Council (the state office defending death row inmates in their appeals) of revealing his private letters to a book author, thus violating [[attorney–client privilege]]. He also accused the agency of running a "death pool," betting on the dates on which inmates would be executed, and asked that the agency be removed from his case.{{cite web | title =The Morgue Archives: Jan-Feb 1999 | work =www.mayhem.net | publisher = Mayhem.net | date = | url = http://www.mayhem.net/Crime/morg9902.html | accessdate = 4 November 2007}} An investigation concluded that these allegations were unfounded. Long's petition for a [[writ of mandamus]] to require Bob Dillinger, the public defender for the Sixth Judicial Circuit, to relinquish possession and control of his file in ''State v. Long,'' was denied. According to the [[Florida Department of Corrections]], Long has one five-year sentence, four 99-year sentences, 28 life sentences, and one death sentence. == Documentaries == The story of Long's crimes was told on: * ''[[The FBI Files]]'', Season 1, episode 7: "Killing Spree" * ''[[Forensic Files]]'', Season 2, episode 1: "The Common Thread" * ''[[I Survived...]]'', Season 2, episode 7 * ''I Escaped My Killer'', Season 1, episode 1, ([[Crime & Investigation Network (Europe)|Crime & Investigation Network]]) * ''Killer Doctors on Death Row'' ([[CBS Reality]]) ==See also== * [[Lonely hearts killer|Want ad killers]] * [[List of death row inmates in the United States]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://law.fsu.edu/library/flsupct/69259/69259brief2.pdf Appeal in and for Hillsborough County, State of Florida] * {{Curlie|Society/Crime/Murder/Serial_Murder/Serial_Killers/Long,_Robert_Joe|Robert Joe Long}} * [http://www.ltn.net/T/Idioma/English/Society/Crime/Murder/Serial_Murder/Serial_Killers/Long,_Robert_Joe/ Serial Killers - Robert Joe Long] * [http://serialkillercalendar.com/bobbyjoelong.html Bobby Joe Long - Bio] * [[The FBI Files]], Season 1 - Ep 7: {{YouTube|id=f1uNHK0MUYg|title="Killing Spree"}} * [[Forensic Files]], Season 2 - Ep 1: {{YouTube|id=4zWP-nfRe8o|title="The Common Thread"}} * Florida Department of Corrections: [http://prod.fdc-wpws001.fdc.myflorida.com/ci/deathrow.html Death Row] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Long, Bobby Joe}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:1984 murders in the United States]] [[Category:American people convicted of burglary]] [[Category:American kidnappers]] [[Category:American people convicted of assault]] [[Category:American people convicted of murder]] [[Category:American prisoners sentenced to death]] [[Category:American rapists]] [[Category:American robbers]] [[Category:American serial killers]] [[Category:Broward College alumni]] [[Category:Crimes against sex workers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Male serial killers]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by Florida]] [[Category:People from Wayne County, West Virginia]] [[Category:Prisoners sentenced to death by Florida]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2017}} The '''Chiasso financial smuggling case''' began on June 3, 2009 near [[Chiasso, Switzerland]] (near the Swiss/Italian border), when Sezione Operativa Territoriale di Chiasso in collaboration with officers of Italian customs/financial military police ([[Guardia di Finanza]]) detained two suspects (who appeared to be [[Japanese people|Japanese nationals]] in their 50s)<ref name=ftd.de>{{cite web |title=Italien rätselt über 96-Mrd.-Euro-Schmuggel |url=http://www.ftd.de/politik/europa/:Kennedy-Bonds-Italien-r%E4tselt-%FCber-96-Mrd-Euro-Schmuggel/526520.html |date=June 13, 2009 |work=Financial Times Deutschland |accessdate=July 6, 2009}}</ref> who had attempted to enter Switzerland with a suitcase in their possession with a false bottom containing what at first appeared to be [[United States Treasury security|U.S. Treasury Bonds]] worth $134.5 billion.<ref name=gdf.it>{{cite web|title=Sequestrati a Chinasso titoli USA per novantasei miliardi di euro |url=http://www.gdf.it/GdF__Informa/Notizie_Stampa/AdnKronos/Adnkronos_2009/Adnkronos_Giugno_2009/info-1518911049.html |date=July 6, 2009 |publisher=Guardia di Finanza |accessdate=July 6, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090613034419/http://www.gdf.it/gdf__informa/notizie_stampa/adnkronos/adnkronos_2009/adnkronos_giugno_2009/info-1518911049.html |archivedate=June 13, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=AsiaNews>{{cite web |title=US government securities seized from Japanese nationals, not clear whether real or fake |url=http://www.asianews.it/index.php?l=en&art=15456&size=A |date=June 8, 2009 |work= |publisher=AsiaNews.it |accessdate=July 6, 2009}}</ref><ref name="jt">{{cite web |title=2 Japanese carrying $134 bil worth of U.S. bonds detained in Italy |url=http://www.japantoday.com/category/crime/view/2-japanese-carrying-134-bil-worth-of-us-bonds-detained-in-italy |archive-url=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20090725152601/http://www.japantoday.com/category/crime/view/2-japanese-carrying-134-bil-worth-of-us-bonds-detained-in-italy |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 25, 2009 |date=June 11, 2009 |work=Japan Today |accessdate=July 6, 2009}}</ref> The two possessed 249 U.S. bonds worth $500 million each (among other securities, they also had 10 "Kennedy bonds" denominated at $1 billion each); and the large denominations of the securities, along with accompanying bank documentation was what attracted the Italian police's attention.<ref name=gdf.it/> Large denominations are not available to the general public; only [[nation-state]]s handle such amounts of money.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}}
==Investigation and determination== Assessment as to the authenticity of the bonds began immediately ([[counterfeiting]] of these securities was suspected). One source reported that the [[Securities and Exchange Commission|U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] had been requested to verify the authenticity of the bonds.<ref name="jt"/> A spokesman for the [[Bureau of Public Debt]] has commented on the matter.{{cn|date=February 2017}}
On June 18, 2009 the ''[[Financial Times]]'' reported that the Italian police and the [[U.S. Secret Service]] had concluded that "the bills and accompanying bank documents were most probably counterfeit, the latest handiwork of the [[Organized crime in Italy|Italian Mafia]]."<ref name=ft.com>{{cite news |title=Mafia blamed for $134bn fake Treasury bills |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/82091ec2-5c2f-11de-aea3-00144feabdc0.html |date=June 18, 2009 |work=Financial Times |access-date=July 6, 2009}}</ref> Though this information has not been verified by Italian official sources. Mckayla Braden, senior adviser for public affairs at the Bureau of Public Debt at the [[U.S. Treasury Department]] also said that this type of counterfeit bond scam "has been going on for years." Although these bonds, if fake, appear to have been of very high quality. Col. Rodolfo Mecarelli, the provincial commander of the financial police in Como, said that the bonds "are made of filigree paper of excellent quality."<ref name=ftd.de/>
The ''Financial Times'' also reported that the two suspects "had been released" by Italian authorities. No additional comment or elaboration from the [[Guardia di Finanza]] (Italian financial/customs military police) headquarters in Rome was available. As well, Ed Donovan, a spokesman for the [[United States Secret Service]], has said that the “U.S. Secret Service, which polices counterfeiting of U.S. currency, is assisting Italian authorities in tracing the source of the fake bonds."<ref>{{cite news |title=UPDATE 1-U.S. Treasury says bonds seized in Italy are fakes |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/companyNewsAndPR/idUSN1946360420090619 |date=June 19, 2009 |work= |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=July 6, 2009 |first=David |last=Lawder}}</ref>
Nonetheless, Japanese authorities also remained interested in the matter; Takeshi Akamatsu, a press secretary for the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Japan)|Japanese foreign ministry]], confirmed that the two suspects were carrying Japanese passports and had been detained and questioned by the Guardia di Finanza, but that Tokyo had not been informed of their names or whereabouts during or after their release.<ref>{{cite web |title=U.S. says smuggled Treasury bonds were fake |url=http://www.gata.org/node/7514 |date=June 21, 2009 |work= |publisher=Gold Anti-Trust Action Committee |accessdate=July 6, 2009}}</ref>
The motivation or likelihood of passing counterfeit bonds of these types and size is not known.
==Reactions and speculation== There has been very little in the way of official statements regarding this case, raising concerns about who made them,<ref name=ft.com/> dumping of U.S. debt<ref>{{cite web|title=Employees of Japan Finance Ministry arrested in Italy trying to smuggle $134 Billion in U.S. Treasuries in suitcases |url=http://www.turnerradionetwork.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=59:employees-of-japan-finance-ministry-arrested-in-italy-trying-tosmuggle-134-billion-in-us-treasuries-in-suitcases&catid=1:latest-news&Itemid=50 |date=June 19, 2009 |work= |publisher=Turner Radio Network |accessdate=February 21, 2012 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> and Italian interests.<ref>{{cite web |title=$134.5 BILLION worth of US bonds seized from smugglers at Swiss border |url=http://www.boingboing.net/2009/06/14/1345-billion-worth-o.html |date=June 14, 2009 |work= |publisher=Boing Boing |accessdate=July 6, 2009}}</ref>
Other questions include the identities of the Japanese men detained, the reason for their release, the origin of these high quality fake bonds, the U.S. Secret Service investigation, lack of Italian official acknowledgment of fakes and many other questions.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Bond Saga: It Gets More Odd |url=http://market-ticker.org/archives/1142-The-Bond-Saga-It-Gets-More-Odd.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20090624133353/http://market-ticker.org/archives/1142-The-Bond-Saga-It-Gets-More-Odd.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=June 24, 2009 |date=June 21, 2009 |work= |publisher=The Market Ticker |accessdate=February 21, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Initial reactions to the story contemplated the possibility that the bonds were genuine; if the bonds had proven to be genuine, this case would have been regarded as the largest single act of [[smuggling]] (with respect to financial value) in recorded history.<ref name=AsiaNews/> The total value of the counterfeit bonds was estimated at approximately one percent of total [[U.S. GDP]] in 2008.<ref>{{cite web |title=Country Comparison: National Product |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2001rank.html |date= |work=The World Factbook |publisher=Central Intelligence Agency |accessdate=July 6, 2009}}</ref> The pair would also have been considered the fourth largest creditor to the U.S., ahead of the [[United Kingdom]] and just behind [[Russia]].<ref name=telegraph>{{cite news |title=Is this the death of the dollar? |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/economics/5586543/Is-this-the-death-of-the-dollar.html |date=June 20, 2009 |work=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=July 6, 2009 | location=London | first=Edmund | last=Conway}}</ref> As well, according to Italian law failing to declare currency above 10,000 euros can be punished by fines of 40%.
Since the confirmation by American officials that the bonds were counterfeit, some reactions have shifted to taking note of a general loss of confidence in [[International finance|international banking and finance]] (in general) and the [[U.S. dollar]] in particular—as noted by a recent downward trend in the [[U.S. Dollar Index]] (and the dollar reaching a new low for 2009 vs. other world currencies on July 28, 2009).<ref>{{cite news|last=Brown |first=Matthew |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aTaWdIwzI_mw |title=Dollar Touches 2009 Low as Economic View Reduces Safety Demand |publisher=Bloomberg.com |date=July 28, 2009 |accessdate=November 7, 2010}}</ref> ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' commentator Edmund Conway noted that when U.S. Treasury Secretary [[Timothy Geithner]] traveled to [[China]] (in June 2009) and asserted in Beijing that Chinese financial assets denominated in the U.S. dollar "are very safe," it drew laughter from the audience, even though laughter was not Geitner's intent.<ref name=telegraph/>
Conway also speculated that this incident may be a sign that "America is on the brink of losing its economic superpower status."<ref name=telegraph/>
==Similar Incidents== On September 18, 2009, a similar incident was reported<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.corriere.it/cronache/09_settembre_20/bond_falsi_delfrate_661f9a3e-a5c6-11de-a2a4-00144f02aabc.shtml |title=Il mistero dei bond falsi Miliardi verso la Svizzera - Corriere della Sera |publisher=Corriere.it |date= |accessdate=November 7, 2010}}</ref> by the Italian financial military police [[Guardia di Finanza]], this time involving two (apparently) [[Philippines|Philippine nationals]] smuggling U.S. Treasury bonds (valued at approximately $180 billion) at [[Malpensa Airport]] (the largest airport in [[Milan, Italy]]). The two were detained and the assessment of this case is on-going.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://rassegnastampa.mef.gov.it/mefeconomica/View.aspx?ID=2009091813722922-2 |title=Libero Quotidiano - Filippini con 180 miliardi nel trolley. Mistero alla dogana di Malpensa |publisher=Rassegnastampa.mef.gov.it |date= |accessdate=November 7, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429235025/http://rassegnastampa.mef.gov.it/mefeconomica/View.aspx?ID=2009091813722922-2 |archivedate=April 29, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
On January 26, 2011, another similar incident was reported<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/business/articles/2011/01/26/italy_confiscates_euro20_billion_in_fake_us_bonds |title=Italy confiscates euro20 billion in fake US bonds|publisher=boston.com |date= January 26, 2011|accessdate=February 21, 2012}}</ref> by the Italian military police [[Carabinieri]], this time involving six smuggling U.S. Treasury bonds (valued at approximately €20 billion and said to be counterfeit) at a highway rest stop. The six are under investigation for receiving stolen goods.
On February 17, 2012, it was reported, Italian police seized $6 trillion in counterfeit U.S. bonds.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financial-crime/9089268/Italian-police-seize-6-trillion-of-fake-US-bonds-in-Switzerland.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Richard | last=Blackden | title=Italian police seize $6 trillion of fake US bonds in Switzerland | date=February 17, 2012}}</ref>
==See also== * [[U.S. Dollar]] * [[Counterfeit United States currency]] * [[Smuggling]] * [[Counterfeiting]] * [[Securities fraud]] * [[Financial crimes]] * [[Organized crime in Italy]] * [[U.S. Dollar Index]] (a general measure of global confidence in the U.S. Dollar)
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.asianews.it/index.php?l=en&art=15648&size=A AsiaNews article about doubts on claims that bonds are fake.] * [http://www.ftd.de/politik/europa/:Kennedy-Bonds-Italien-r%E4tselt-%FCber-96-Mrd-Euro-Schmuggel/526520.html Financial Times Deutschland story on the age of Japanese men] * [https://www.reuters.com/article/companyNewsAndPR/idUSN1946360420090619 Secret Service is Investigating] * [http://dealbook.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/06/26/italy-intercepts-billions-in-fake-treasuries/ NY Times Story] * [http://www.asianews.it/index.php?l=en&art=15456&size=A If the bonds are confirmed, then it is the largest financial smuggling operation in history.] * [http://www.nationalterroralert.com/updates/2009/06/11/2-japanese-carrying-134-billion-in-us-bonds-detained-in-italy/ This source stated that the SEC has been asked to authenticate the bonds.] * [https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2001rank.html The CIA's estimate of U.S. GDP in 2008 was $14.3 Trillion.] * [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/82091ec2-5c2f-11de-aea3-00144feabdc0.html Bonds are counterfeit and, curiously, the two suspects were released.] * [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/economics/5586543/Is-this-the-death-of-the-dollar.html In the Telegraph, commentator Edmund Conway stated that this story points to falling global confidence in the U.S. Dollar.] * [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aTaWdIwzI_mw Bloomberg report that U.S. Dollar reached a new low in 2009 vs. other world currencies] * [http://www.corriere.it/cronache/09_settembre_20/bond_falsi_delfrate_661f9a3e-a5c6-11de-a2a4-00144f02aabc.shtml A similar case]

'''Compounding treason''' is an offence under the [[common law]] of England. It is committed by anyone who agrees for [[Consideration in English law|consideration]] to abstain from prosecuting the offender who has committed [[treason]].
It is still an offence in England and Wales,<ref>The [[Criminal Law Act 1967]] (c.58), section 5(5)</ref> and in Northern Ireland.<ref>The [[Criminal Law Act (Northern Ireland) 1967]] (c.18) (N.I.), section 5(5)</ref> It has been abolished in the Republic of Ireland.<ref>The [[Criminal Law Act 1997]] (No.14), section 8(3)</ref>
In 1977 [[Law Commission (England and Wales)|the Law Commission]] recommended that the offence should be abolished for England and Wales and for Northern Ireland.
==See also== * [[Compounding a felony]] * [[Misprision of treason]] * [[High treason in the United Kingdom]]
==References== *The Law Commission (1977). Treason, Sedition and Allied Offences (Working Paper No.72), paragraphs 6, 43, 67 and 96(5).[http://www.bailii.org/ew/other/EWLC/1977/c72.html BAILII] {{reflist}}

{{Infobox company | name = Cyberian Outpost, Inc. | logo = Cyberian Outpost Logo.png | logo_size = 332px | type = [[Public company]] | traded_as = {{NASDAQ|COOL}} | foundation = 1995<ref name=8K/> | fate = Acquired | successor = [[Fry's Electronics]] | founder = Darryl Peck | defunct = {{End date|2001}} | location_city = [[Kent, Connecticut]] | location_country = [[United States]] | industry = [[E-commerce]] | products = Computer hardware & software | revenue = {{increase}} [[United States dollar|US$]]355 million (2001)<ref name=8K>[http://pdf.secdatabase.com/2236/0000927016-01-502790.pdf CYBERIAN OUTPOST INC FORM 8-K]</ref> | num_employees = 300<ref name=kentschool>{{cite news | url=http://www.nhregister.com/article/NH/20130319/NEWS/303199840 | title=Kent School alum purchases former 'Outpost.com' building for school use | first=Kathryn | last=Boughton | publisher=[[New Haven Register]] | date=March 19, 2013}}</ref> | homepage = {{URL|http://outpost.com/}} }}
'''Cyberian Outpost''' was an online vendor of discount computer hardware and software that operated the website outpost.com. After its IPO in 1998, it reached a peak [[market capitalization]] of $1 billion, but, after the bursting of the [[dot-com bubble]], its stock price fell rapidly and the company was acquired by [[Fry's Electronics]] in 2001 for $21 million.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/07/24/business/markets-market-place-cyberian-outpost-plunges-toward-abyss-two-suitors-wait.html | title=As Cyberian Outpost plunges toward the abyss, two suitors wait patiently to pick up the pieces | first=LAURIE J. | last=FLYNN | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=July 24, 2001}}</ref>
The company received publicity for its controversial advertisements including one in which gerbils were shot out of a cannon, one where wolves attack a high school marching band, and one where children in daycare are being tattooed with "outpost.com" on their foreheads.
==History== Cyberian Outpost was founded in 1995 by Darryl Peck.<ref name=8K/>
Cyberian Outpost was one of the earliest successful online-only retailers. Unlike many large retailers of the time, the company marketed directly to expert consumers instead of businesses and specialized in hard-to-find Macintosh products in a market saturated with Microsoft-compatible products. Outpost.com marketed its products around the world and offered its website in 11 languages and sold to customers in 140 countries.<ref name=parry>{{cite journal | ssrn=910080 | title=Cyberian Outpost | first=Mark E. | last=Parry | date=October 21, 2008}}</ref><ref name=S1/>
The company expanded rapidly, taking advantage of the booming Internet. Revenue increased from $1.9 million in the year ended February 29, 1996 to $22.7 million in the year ended February 28, 1998.<ref name=S1/>
In 1997, ''[[Money Magazine]]'' rated the site as "Best Site for Computer Equipment".<ref name=parry/><ref name=S1>[http://www.nasdaq.com/markets/ipos/filing.ashx?filingid=706243 CYBERIAN OUTPOST, INC. Form S-1]</ref> Outpost.com raised $2.7 million in venture capital in 1997, at which point the site had 25,000 visitors per day and 1.3 million customers.<ref name=kentschool/> The company secured another $22 million in financing in 1998,<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/cyberian-outpost-initiates-ceo-search-to-continue-momentum-seeks-executive-to-lead-next-phase-of-growth-and-corporate-development-74340382.html | title=Cyberian Outpost Initiates CEO Search to Continue Momentum; Seeks Executive to Lead Next Phase of Growth and Corporate Development | publisher=[[PRNewswire]] | date=May 3, 1999}}</ref> and raised another $70 million from its [[initial public offering]].<ref name=kentschool/> Outpost.com opened a warehouse in Ohio that could guarantee next-morning domestic delivery and worldwide delivery within 48 hours.<ref name=parry/>
After the [[dot-com bubble]] burst, the company fell on hard times. In 2001, the company entered into a merger agreement with [[PC Connection]] but then terminated that merger agreement and the company was sold to [[Fry's Electronics]] for $21 million including the repayment of $13 million in debt from PC Connection.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/frys-electronics-inc-to-acquire-cyberian-outpost-inc-71899852.html | title=Fry's Electronics, Inc. to Acquire Cyberian Outpost, Inc. | publisher=[[PRNewswire]] | date=August 31, 2001}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/cyberian-outpost-inc-and-pc-connection-inc-terminate-merger-71924337.html | title=Cyberian Outpost, Inc. and PC Connection, Inc. Terminate Merger | publisher=[[PRNewswire]] | date=September 4, 2001}}</ref><ref name=8K/><ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/outpostcom-announces-completion-of-its-merger-with-frys-electronics-74153182.html | title=Outpost.com Announces Completion of its Merger with Fry's Electronics | publisher=[[PRNewswire]] | date=November 8, 2001}}</ref> At that time, the company had 1.4 million customers and 4 million visitors per month to its website.<ref name=8K/>
==Marketing== Outpost.com forged marketing partnerships with major [[Internet portal]]s, such as [[AOL]], [[CNet]], and [[Lycos]]<ref>[http://corporate.findlaw.com/contracts/operations/agreement-lycos-bertelsmann-gmbh-and-cyberian-outpost-inc.html/ Agreement - Lycos-Bertelsmann GmbH. and Cyberian Outpost Inc.]</ref> in which Outpost.com was featured on these popular websites.<ref name=S1/>
Outpost.com hired Cliff Freeman to produce TV ads, whose agency had created the "Pizza Pizza" campaign for [[Little Caesars]] and the "Where's the Beef?" campaigns for [[Wendy's International]].<ref name=parry/><ref>{{cite web | url=http://adage.com/article/agency-news/advertising-agency-cliff-freeman-slips-history-books/140123/ | title=Where's the Shop? Cliff Freeman Slips Into History Books | first=Kunur | last=Patel | publisher=[[Ad Age]] | date=November 2, 2009}}</ref> Outpost.com adopted a zealous and controversial marketing program which included a Super Bowl ad in which fake gerbils were shot out of a cannon at the company logo,<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fzbMcsrK-tw Gerbils shot out of a cannon]</ref> followed later by an ad that featured a high school marching band being attacked by a pack of ravenous wolves,<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9cmT8M_67ow Wolves attack a high school marching band]</ref> and another ad portraying pre-school toddlers being tattooed with 'Outpost.com' across their foreheads.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-SjMjZQGoHw Children in Daycare being tattooed with "outpost.com" on their foreheads]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * Outpost.com TV Ad: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fzbMcsrK-tw Gerbils shot out of a cannon] * Outpost.com TV Ad: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9cmT8M_67ow Wolves attack a high school marching band] * Outpost.com TV Ad: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-SjMjZQGoHw Children in Daycare being tattooed with "outpost.com" on their foreheads]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:History of Myanmar]]; added [[Category:History of Myanmar (1948–present)]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
Official reports from the [[government]] of [[Myanmar]] (Burma) cite a death toll of 90 due to the [[tsunami]] caused by the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake]] on 26 December 2004.<ref>McElroy, Damien (January 2, 2005). [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/burmamyanmar/1480258/Our-government-in-Burma-is-lying-when-it-says-just-a-few-people-were-killed.html 'Our government in Burma is lying when it says just a few people were killed']. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''.</ref> However, some estimates put the toll at between 400 and 600.<ref>Associated Press (January 4, 2005). [http://www.theage.com.au/news/Breaking-News/Scientists-question-Burmas-low-toll/2005/01/04/1104601354278.html?oneclick=true Scientists question Burma's low toll]. ''[[The Age]]''.</ref> 30,000 citizens of Myanmar were estimated to be in need of shelter, food and water,<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/4145489.stm 'Hundreds feared dead' in Burma]. [[BBC News]]. January 4, 2005.</ref> and 788 buildings were reported damaged and destroyed.<ref>Inbaraj, Sonny (January 5, 2005). [http://www.ipsnews.net/interna.asp?idnews=26914 Tsunami Impact: Burma 'Spared' or Junta Covering the Truth?] [[Inter Press Service]].</ref>
An NGO estimated that 2,500 citizens of Myanmar based in [[Phang Nga Province]], [[Thailand]] during the event may have been killed, and that 7,000 Burmese were still unaccounted for.<ref>AFP (January 18, 2005). [http://www.theage.com.au/news/Asia-tsunami/Indonesia-drops-foreign-troops-deadline/2005/01/17/1105810800330.html Indonesia drops foreign troops deadline]. ''[[The Age]]''.</ref> Many of these missing were, however, not presumed to be dead. Many refugees fled to Thailand's interior after the destruction,<ref>Associated Press (January 22, 2005). [http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2005/1/22/latest/20899Myanmarwo&sec=latest Myanmar workers forgotten victims of tsunami in Thailand]. ''[[The Star (Malaysia)]]''.</ref> or were deported or chased back into the hills that divide the countries by Thai authorities.<ref>Inbaraj, Sonny (January 13, 2005). [http://www.ipsnews.org/interna.asp?idnews=27021 Tsuanmi Impact: Thai Compassion for Burmese Migrants Wears Thin]. [[Inter Press Service]].</ref>
Although loss of life and property in Myanmar was suspected to be higher than official reports suggest, loss of life was not as high as in neighbouring [[Thailand]] due to various factors, most significantly the numerous islands off the coast of Myanmar which served to dissipate the force of the tsunami, a rocky shoreline, and the position of the coastline.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2005/WORLD/asiapcf/01/05/tsunami.myanmar/index.html Rocky shoreline helped Myanmar]. [[CNN]]. January 5, 2005.</ref> Also contributing is the fact that it is less developed than neighboring Thailand; international disapproval of the [[State Peace and Development Council|Burmese military regime]] has prevented the country from building a successful [[tourism]] industry.
A [[Yangon]]-based representative from the [[United Nations]] stated, "Conjecture fuelled by the experiences in neighbouring countries created a major and dangerous disconnect with reality". This assessment was also corroborated by [[satellite]] photographs according to [[Colin Powell]].<ref>Reuters (January 6, 2005). [http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=story_6-1-2005_pg4_23 Secretive Myanmar remains tsunami news black hole]. ''[[Daily Times (Pakistan)]]''.</ref>
Myanmar does not allow journalists into the country and maintains a [[Censorship in Burma|strong hold on information]] disseminated in its [[State media|state-run]] newspapers - some of which did not acknowledge the tsunami had hit.<ref>Estrella, Cicero A. (December 31, 2004). [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/chronicle/a/2004/12/31/MNGPTAJDG61.DTL BURMA: Expert fears deaths underreported]. ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]''.</ref> Burma had refused foreign aid, insisting it was capable to cope by itself.<ref>Moe, Kyaw Zwa (December 31, 2004). [http://www.irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=4252&page=1 Burma Regime Rejects Offers of Disaster Aid]. ''[[The Irrawaddy]]''.</ref> This policy has created a difficult environment to gauge the lives affected by the tsunami.
==References== {{reflist|2}}
