{{Infobox military person |name=Elmer Gedeon |birth_date={{birth date|mf=yes|1917|4|15}} |death_date={{death date and age|mf=yes|1944|4|20|1917|4|15}} |birth_place=[[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]] |death_place=[[Saint-Pol-sur-Ternoise|Saint-Pol]], [[France]] |placeofburial=[[Arlington National Cemetery]] |placeofburial_label=Place of burial |image=Elmer Gedeon.jpg |caption= |allegiance={{flag|United States of America}} |branch=[[File:US Army Air Corps Hap Arnold Wings.svg|25px]] [[United States Army Air Forces]] |serviceyears=1941–1944 |rank=[[File:Army-USA-OF-02.svg|25px]] [[Captain (OF-2)|Captain]] |commands= |unit=[[586th Flight Test Squadron|586th Bomb Squadron]], [[394th Bombardment Group]] |battles=World War II
[[European Theater of Operations]] |awards=[[Image:Soldier's Medal ribbon.svg|25px]] [[Soldier's Medal]]
[[Image:Purple Heart BAR.svg|25px|border]] [[Purple Heart]] |relations= |laterwork= |alma_mater=[[University of Michigan]] }} '''Elmer John Gedeon''' (April 15, 1917 – April 20, 1944) was a professional baseball player, appearing in several games for the [[Washington Senators (1901–60)|Washington Senators]] in {{mlby|1939}}. Gedeon and [[Harry O'Neill (catcher)|Harry O'Neill]] were the only two [[Major League Baseball]] players killed during [[World War II]]. Gedeon flew several missions in the [[European Theater of Operations]] as an officer of the [[United States Army Air Forces]] before being shot down over France. During college at the [[University of Michigan]], Gedeon became an [[All-American]] in [[track and field]], and earned [[varsity letter]]s in both [[American football|football]] and [[baseball]]. He tied a [[world record]] in the high [[Hurdling|hurdles]] in 1938. After graduating, Gedeon had a stint in Major League Baseball as an [[outfielder]] for the [[Washington Senators (1901–60)|Washington Senators]]. Gedeon spent most of the 1939 and 1940 baseball seasons in the minor leagues, but he was called up to the Senators in September 1939. Gedeon's baseball career was cut short when he was [[military draft|drafted]] by the [[United States Army]] in early 1941. He trained as a [[bomber]] pilot, and was decorated for bravery after his plane crashed on a training flight in 1942. He later served in combat, and was shot down and killed while [[Aviator|piloting]] a [[B-26 Marauder|B-26 bomber]] on a mission over France in April 1944. == Growing up in Cleveland == Born in [[Cleveland]], Gedeon was a star athlete at Cleveland's [[West High School (Cleveland)|West High School]], where he was a member of the class of 1935.{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:CPDB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0F8035370FB7CEAF&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Modell Says Browns Will Return To Top|accessdate=2008-12-23|date=1991-11-18|agency=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[The Plain Dealer]]|author=Heaton, Chuck}}{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:CPDB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0F80D09024FE94DD&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Missing Plaque A Part of History|accessdate=2008-12-23|date=1998-09-24|agency=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[The Plain Dealer]]|author=Dirck, Joe}} He was a {{height|ft=6|in=4}} athlete who excelled in American football, baseball, and [[track and field]]. While [[ice skating]] in [[Old Brooklyn|Brookside Park]] in Cleveland as a youth, the ice gave way and Gedeon's cousin plunged through up to his neck. The cousin later recalled: "Elmer slid across the ice on his belly and pulled me out." Gedeon's uncle, [[Joe Gedeon]], was a [[Major League Baseball]] player who was implicated in the [[Black Sox Scandal|Chicago Black Sox scandal]].{{cite web|url=http://bioproj.sabr.org/bioproj.cfm?a=v&v=l&pid=4991&bid=238|accessdate=2007-12-07|title=Joe Gedeon|author=Swaine, Rick|publisher=The Society for American Baseball Research (SABR) & The Respective Authors}} Gedeon's [[surname]] was common in Cleveland, because many people from [[Sudetenland]], where it was common, settled in Cleveland. The phonebook listed numerous Gedeons for biographical research. One finding was that Gedeon's widow, who was named Laura, later moved to Florida. Another was that his third cousin Charlotte Gedeon said Elmer carried her grandmother's [[casket]] during a funeral. == Collegiate athletics == [[File:Elmer John Gedeon.png|thumb|right|155px|Gedeon from 1939 ''Michiganensian'']] Gedeon enrolled at the [[University of Michigan]] in 1935 where he earned [[varsity letter]]s in three sports: baseball, football, and track and field.{{cite news|last=Rubin|first=Neal|title=U-M athlete's selflessness predated sacrifices in WWII|work=[[The Detroit News]]|date=2005-05-29}} Gedeon's best sport was track and field, in which he was a two-time [[Big Ten Conference]] champion in the outdoor [[110 metre hurdles|120-yard high hurdles]] and indoor [[60 metre hurdles|70-yard high hurdles]].{{cite news|author=Bedingfield, Gary|title=Elmer Gedeon|url=http://www.baseballlibrary.com/baseballlibrary/submit/Bedingfield_Gary2.stm |publisher=BaseballLibrary.com|date=2001-05-22|accessdate=2009-01-10 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071023083043/http://www.baseballlibrary.com/baseballlibrary/submit/Bedingfield_Gary2.stm |archivedate = 2007-10-23}}{{cite web|url=http://bigten.cstv.com/auto_pdf/p_hotos/s_chools/big10/genrel/auto_pdf/0708records-men-track|title=Big Ten Conference Records Book 2007-08: Men's Track and Field|accessdate=2008-01-05|year=2007|publisher=Big Ten Conference, Inc.}}{{cite book|title=Two Thousand Eight Michigan Men's Track & Field|editor=Hergott, Jeremiah|publisher=Frye Printing Company|year=2008}} In March 1938, Gedeon tied the American indoor record in the {{convert|70|yd|adj=on}} high hurdles at the Big Ten meet in [[Chicago]].{{cite news|title=Michigan Carries Off Meet, Badgers, Ohio State Shine|work=The Brainerd Daily Dispatch (Minn.)|date=1938-03-14}} He went on to tie a world record in the Illinois Relays, and then won the Big Ten title despite an injury.{{cite news|author=Snider, Steve|title=Star Trio Tops Bids of Wolves in Big Ten Test|work=[[Mason City Globe-Gazette]]|date=1939-03-10}} He also led Michigan to victory in the March 1939 Big Ten indoor track and field meet in Chicago.{{cite news|title=Michigan Star Elmer Gedeon|work=[[Nevada State Journal]]|date=1939-03-21}} Michigan won both the Big Ten outdoor and indoor championships in 1938–1939. At the 1938 outdoor [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] championships, he placed third in the {{convert|120|yd|adj=on}} hurdles and became an All-American in track and field. Gedeon also wore #51 for the [[Michigan Wolverines football]] program from [[1936 Michigan Wolverines football team|1936]] to [[1938 Michigan Wolverines football team|1938]],{{cite web|url=http://141.211.39.65/allroster/fbsearch.htm|accessdate=2007-11-04|date=2003-08-25|title=Bentley Historical Library -- -- U of M Football Rosters|publisher=The Regents of the University of Michigan|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928200732/http://141.211.39.65/allroster/fbsearch.htm |archivedate = September 28, 2007|deadurl=yes}} earning three varsity letters in football. In 1937, a feature article on the Michigan team noted that, in addition to his abilities as an end, "Gedeon can pass and punt, and can run faster than any one on the squad."{{cite news|author=Stauter, George|title=Vets, Not Sophs, Showing Best Wares Among Wolves|work=[[The Post-Crescent]]|date=1937-09-30}} In 1938, Gedeon played [[End (American football)|end]] in Coach [[Fritz Crisler]]'s first season as Michigan's football coach. That was the year that Coach Crisler introduced the "[[winged football helmet]]" at Michigan. Team [[Captain (sports)|captain]] Fred Janke recalled Gedeon was "a tall, skinny guy", at {{convert|6|ft|4|in|m|2}} and {{convert|196|lb|kg st}}. "A rather serious kid. He could kick quite well. They used to pull him back in serious situations and let him [[Punt (gridiron football)|punt]] the ball, because he could punt it a mile." In baseball, Gedeon played both [[first base]] and the [[outfield]] for the [[Michigan Wolverines baseball]] team. He was a two-time letterman in baseball and batted .320.{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:DNPB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0EAF452B1CC24F8A&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=Remember Gedeon each Memorial Day Big leaguers died in World War II|accessdate=2008-12-23|date=1999-05-30|agency=[[Newsbank]]|work=[[The Denver Post]]|author=Frei, Terry}} == Professional baseball == {{Infobox baseball biography |name = Elmer Gedeon |image = |caption = Gedeon playing at the [[University of Michigan]] |width = 250 |position = Outfielder |bats = Right |throws = Right |birth_date = |death_date = |debutleague = MLB |debutdate = September 18 |debutyear = 1939 |debutteam = Washington Senators |finalleague = MLB |finaldate = September 24 |finalyear = 1939 |finalteam = Washington Senators |statleague = MLB |stat1label = [[Games played]] |stat1value = 5 |stat2label = [[At bat]]s |stat2value = 15 |stat3label = [[Hit (baseball)|Hits]] |stat3value = 3 |teams = * [[Washington Senators (1901–60)|Washington Senators]] (1939) }} Gedeon signed with the [[Washington Senators (1901–60)|Washington Senators]] after graduating in the summer of 1939. He chose to sign with the Senators over a possible appearance as a member of the USA's track team in the [[1940 Summer Olympics]]. Gedeon was quite a prospect; [[Clark Griffith]], president of the Senators, mentioned Gedeon to ''[[The Sporting News]]'' on June 15, when talking about exciting new players: "We've got ... a youngster from the University of Michigan named Gedeon." Gedeon was initially assigned to a [[minor league baseball]] team in [[Orlando, Florida]] where he played in 67 games in 1939.{{cite news|author=Morris, R.|title=Remembering World War II airmen: Website remembers baseball players killed in World War Two|publisher=Untold Valor|date=2007-06-24|url=http://untoldvalor.blogspot.com/2007/06/website-remembers-baseball-players.html|accessdate=2007-12-02}} In mid-September, he was called up to the major leagues where he appeared in five games as an outfielder with three hits, one run and one RBI.{{cite news|title=Elmer Gedeon Major League Baseball Career Statistics|publisher=BR.com|date=2007-10-28|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/g/gedeoel01.shtml|accessdate=2007-12-02}} His three hits came in a 10–9 win against the [[Cleveland Indians]] on September 19 as the starting [[centerfielder]]. In his five major league games, he played four games in center field and one in [[right field]]. In 1940, Gedeon attended spring training with the Senators in Orlando, seeking a spot in the outfield or first base. In February 1940, newspapers ran a wire service photograph of Gedeon hurdling over Senators first baseman [[Jimmy Wasdell]], supposedly "by way of warming up".{{cite news|title=Hurdler To Try Majors|work=The News-Palladium (Benton Harbor, Mich.)|date=1940-02-19}} returned to the minor leagues where he played for the [[Charlotte Hornets (baseball)|Charlotte Hornets]] (in the [[Piedmont League]]) and hit .271 in 131 games. He was again recalled in September, but he made no appearances in any games. It appeared 1941 would see Gedeon moving to play more minor league baseball for either Greenville or Springfield. In the interim Gedeon served as an assistant football coach at Michigan. == Military service and death in World War II == Gedeon was drafted into the military in January 1941, and reported to the Army instead of spring training. He was inducted at [[Fort Thomas, Kentucky]] and reported to the Cavalry Replacement Center at [[Fort Riley]] on March 18. He immediately became an acting [[Corporal#United States|corporal]] of Troop B of the First Squadron for the thirteen-week training program. The Bentley Historical Library at the University of Michigan owns a copy of an April 1941 [[Fraternities and sororities|fraternity]] newsletter with a note from Gedeon. "As you probably know by this time", he wrote to his [[Phi Gamma Delta]] brothers, "Old Ged has been drafted." On being assigned to the cavalry, Gedeon joked in the letter to his fraternity that "the only horse I ever saw in my life was the one the milkman used." On October 22, 1941, Gedeon was accepted into pilot training despite his size and transferred to the [[United States Army Air Forces]], earning his [[pilot's wings]] and a commission as a [[second lieutenant#United States|second lieutenant]] at [[Williams Air Force Base|Williams Field, Arizona]] in May 1942. He undertook twin-engined bomber training with the [[21st Operations Group|21st Bomb Group]] at [[MacDill Field]] in [[Tampa, Florida]]. Gedeon's usual duties were to aid in European mission planning from a desk.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/26/sports/baseball/remembering-the-major-leaguers-who-died-in-world-war-ii.html|title=Two Who Did Not Return|accessdate=2013-05-26|date=2013-05-26|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Weintraub, Robert}} On August 9, 1942, Gedeon was flying as the [[navigator]] in a [[B-25]] that crashed in the middle of a swamp on take off from the municipal airport at [[Raleigh, North Carolina]].{{cite news|title=Athlete Hurt in Crash of Bomber|work=The News-Palladium (Benton Harbor, Mich.)|date=1942-08-10}} Gedeon crawled from the burning bomber, and despite burns and three broken ribs, he went back into the wreckage, rescuing a crewmate, Corporal John R. Rarrat, who had suffered a broken back and two broken legs.{{cite news|title=Elmer Gedeon War Hero|work=[[San Antonio Express]]|date=1943-03-08}} Two crew members died in the crash, and Gedeon spent 12 weeks in the hospital recovering from his broken ribs and burns to his back, hands, face and legs, some requiring skin grafts. He lost {{convert|50|lbs|kg|1}} in recovery. [[first lieutenant|First Lt.]] Gedeon was awarded the [[Soldier's Medal]] for heroism and bravery by Major General [[St. Clair Streett]] in what was described as "one of the most colorful ceremonies ever held at MacDill Field. "I'll be back in baseball after the war", he had said on his last [[Leave (military)|leave]] before going overseas.{{cite news|author=Kuper, Simon |title=Stars saved from ultimate pitched battle |work=[[Financial Times]] |date=2005-05-07 |url=http://hnn.us/readcomment.php?id=60366&bheaders=1 |accessdate=2007-12-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060527202059/http://hnn.us/readcomment.php?id=60366&bheaders=1 |archivedate=May 27, 2006 }} Gedeon's cousin recalled: "The last time I saw him, he told me, 'I had my accident. It's going to be good flying from now on.' He said he had used up his bad luck." In February 1943, the [[Associated Press]] ran a feature story about Gedeon's war service under the headline: "Gedeon Will Return to Baseball If War Doesn’t Last Too Long."{{cite news|title=Gedeon Will Return to Baseball If War Doesn’t Last Too Long|work=The Times Recorder (Zanesville, Ohio)|date=1943-02-10}} Gedeon was quoted in the article as saying "he hopes to pick up after the war where he left off." He added that "it's a matter of time." "If the war ends before I’m past the playing age I’ll return to the game. If I’m too old, I’ll do something else." [[File:394bg-boreham-2.jpg|thumb|B-26 Marauder of the 394th Bomb Group at RAF Boreham.]] In July 1943, Gedeon was among personnel from the 21st BG that became the cadre of the [[586th Flight Test Squadron|586th Bomb Squadron]], [[394th Bombardment Group]] [[United States Army Air Forces]], formed to train with Martin [[B-26 Marauder]]s. At [[Ardmore Air Force Base|Ardmore Army Air Field]], [[Oklahoma]], he participated in group operational training in preparation for combat. In February 1944, the group was sent to [[RAF Boreham]], England, to become part of the [[Ninth Air Force]]. Gedeon was assigned as Squadron Operations Officer and began flying combat missions in Europe.{{cite web|url=http://www.baseballinwartime.com/player_biographies/gedeon_elmer.htm|title=Elmer Gedeon|accessdate=2007-12-07|publisher=Gary Bedingfield (Baseball in Wartime)|date=2007-05-19|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080407224822/http://www.garybed.co.uk/player_biographies/gedeon_elmer.htm |archivedate = April 7, 2008|deadurl=no}} His first mission was to attack an airfield at [[Beaumont-le-Roger]], France, on March 23, 1944. On April 20, 1944, Gedeon piloted one of 36 B-26's that left Boreham in the late afternoon to attack a [[V-1 (flying bomb)|V-1 "buzz bomb"]] site being constructed at [[Esquerdes]], a village in the [[Pas-de-Calais]] near [[Saint-Omer]]. Led by Capt. [[Darrell Lindsey]], it was the group's thirteenth mission. Attacking after dusk from 12,000 feet, the group encountered intense and accurate anti-aircraft fire, and Gedeon's plane was hit by [[flak]] below the cockpit just after bombing. Gedeon's co-pilot, his clothes on fire, was able to [[parachute]] from the bomber as it plunged towards the ground, but Gedeon and five other crew members were killed.{{cite web | last =Bedingfield| first =Gary| authorlink = | year =2010 | url= http://www.seamheads.com/2010/07/13/elmer-gedeon-a-true-hero-of-world-war-ii/|title = Elmer Gedeon: A True Hero of World War II| work = | publisher = seamheads.com| accessdate= 2011-01-09}} Gedeon was initially reported as missing in action and it was not until May 1945 that his family received word that his grave had been located in a small British army cemetery at [[Saint-Pol-sur-Ternoise|Saint-Pol]], France.{{cite news|author=Painting, Harry|title=In This Corner By Harry Painting|work=The Lethbridge Herald|location=England|date=1945-05-16}} Gedeon's body was later returned to the United States, and he was buried at [[Arlington National Cemetery]]. Of the 500-plus major league players who served in the military in World War II,{{cite news|last=Weintraub|first=Robert|title=Two Who Did Not Return|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/26/sports/baseball/remembering-the-major-leaguers-who-died-in-world-war-ii.html|accessdate=26 May 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=26 May 2013}} Gedeon and [[Harry O'Neill (catcher)|Harry O'Neill]] were the only players killed, both at age 27. The two have become symbols of "baseball's sacrifice" in the war effort. As the [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum]] proclaims: "Ballplayers, like every other American citizen, understand the importance of giving one's self for their country." After the war, a scholarship in Gedeon's name was established at the University of Michigan.{{cite news|title=Grid Star To U-M|work=[[Traverse City Record-Eagle]]|date=1953-06-04}} Gedeon was inducted into the [[University of Michigan Athletic Hall of Honor]] for track and baseball in 1983. He was the sixth Michigan athlete inducted for his contributions in multiple sports.{{cite web|url=http://www.letterwinnersmclub.com/hallofhonor.html|title=Hall of Honor|accessdate=2007-12-07|publisher=letterwinnersmclub.com}} ==Awards and decorations==

{{refimprove|date=May 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox recurring event | image = Facebook F8 Developer's Conference 2017 (33324521213).jpg | imagesize = frameless | caption = Facebook F8 2017 at [[San Jose Convention Center|McEnery Convention Center]] in [[San Jose, California]] | begins = | ends = | date = | frequency = Annual | venue = [[San Jose Convention Center]] | location = [[San Jose, California|San Jose]] | founded = | last = | participants = | attendance = | footnotes = | organized = [[Facebook]] | website = {{URL|www.f8.com}} }}
'''Facebook F8''' (pronounced "''eff eight''") is a mostly-annual conference held by [[Facebook]], intended for developers and entrepreneurs who build products and services around the website. It is hosted in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]], [[California]], previously in [[San Francisco]] (until 2016) and now in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], in [[Silicon Valley]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/f8?sk=app_110713442293217|title=f8 - In Review: f8 2010|last=|first=|date=|publisher=Facebook|url-access=registration|accessdate=July 8, 2013}}</ref> Previous events have started with a keynote speech by Facebook founder [[Mark Zuckerberg]], followed by various breakout sessions concentrating on specific topics. Facebook has often introduced new features, and made new announcements, at the conference.
The "F8" name comes from Facebook's tradition of 8 hour [[hackathon]]s.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/2010/04/21/facebook-pushes-to-make-the-web-more-instantly-social/|title=Facebook pushes to make the Web more ‘instantly social’ – The Mercury News|access-date=2017-03-14}}</ref>
The scheduling of F8 has been somewhat erratic. No conferences were held in 2009, 2012 or 2013, and the date for the 2011 conference was announced late in the year.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/04/24/yes-facebook-developers-there-will-be-an-f8-this-year/|first=Alexia|last=Tsotsis|title= Yes Facebook Developers, There Will Be An f8 This Year|work=[[TechCrunch]]|date=April 25, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://allthingsd.com/20120917/sorry-developers-dont-expect-facebooks-f8-conference-this-year/|title=Sorry, Developers: Don't Expect Facebook's F8 Conference This Year|last=Isaac|first=Mike|date=September 17, 2012|accessdate=July 8, 2013|work=AllThingsD}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.webpronews.com/facebook-skips-on-hosting-the-f8-conference-this-year-2012-09|title=Facebook Skips On Hosting The F8 Conference This Year|last=Walton|first=Zach|date=September 18, 2012|publisher=WebProNews|accessdate=July 8, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://venturebeat.com/2012/09/17/no-f8/|title=Destiny be damned, Facebook not holding f8 this year|date=September 17, 2012|work=VentureBeat|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303182553/http://venturebeat.com/2012/09/17/no-f8/|archive-date=March 3, 2016|dead-url=no|accessdate=July 8, 2013}}</ref>
==2007== The first F8 event was held on May 24, 2007, at the San Francisco Design Center in [[San Francisco]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://newsroom.fb.com/news/2007/05/facebook-unveils-platform-for-developers-of-social-applications/|title=Facebook Unveils Platform for Developers of Social Applications|date=May 24, 2007|work=Facebook Newsroom|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> The notion of the [[social graph]] was introduced.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2007/05/24/facebook-launches-facebook-platform-they-are-the-anti-myspace/|title=Facebook Launches Facebook Platform; They are the Anti-MySpace|last=Arrington|first=Michael|date=May 25, 2007|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140702194557/http://techcrunch.com/2007/05/24/facebook-launches-facebook-platform-they-are-the-anti-myspace/|archive-date=July 2, 2014|dead-url=no|access-date=May 2, 2018|work=TechCrunch}}</ref>
==2008== The 2008 F8 event was held July 23, 2008, at the San Francisco Design Center once again. News and announcements from this event included:
* Introducing the New Facebook Profile & More * Integrating Facebook Connect into your Website
==2010== The 2010 F8 event was held April 21, 2010 at the San Francisco Design Center. The main announcement was the feature to add a “Like” button to any piece of content on a website by the owner.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2010/03/25/facebook-to-release-a-like-button-for-the-whole-darn-internet/|title=Facebook To Release A “Like” Button For the Whole Darn Internet|first=Michael|last=Arrington|date=March 26, 2010|work=TechCrunch}}</ref> This feature is now integrated within around 2.5 million websites worldwide, with 10,000 more being added daily.
Additional news and announcements included:
* Social Plugins (e.g. [[Like button]]) * Open Graph Protocol * Graph API * OAuth 2.0
==2011== F8 2011 was held on September 22, 2011.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/appsblog/2011/sep/22/facebook-f8-mark-zuckerberg-social-live|title=Facebook f8: Mark Zuckerberg on music, media and social apps – Thursday 22 September 2011|last=Dredge|first=Stuart|date=September 22, 2011|website=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/09/22/f8-2011-facebook-announcements_n_976540.html|title=F8 2011: Facebook's 7 Biggest Announcements From The Event|last=Emerson|first=Ramona|date=September 23, 2011|work=Huffington Post|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> Various things Facebook introduced at the conference included a new profile redesign named 'Timeline' that showed a history of user's activity on their profile, and a broader, more advanced version of the 'Open Graph' protocol.
The F8 2011 event was mainly focused on introducing new products, transforming industries, building and growing social applications and product Q&A. Some of the details of the topics were:
* The Future of Digital Music * Mobile + Social * The Rise of Social Gaming * Investing in Social * Developing Products at Facebook * Social Design * Distribution: Growing on Facebook * Marketing on Facebook * Hack Better: New Tools for Developers * Inside HTML5 Development at Facebook * Making Fast Social Apps
==2014== <gallery class="float right" perrow="1" widths="200px" heights="170px"> File:Move Fast and Break Things (14071866872) (cropped).jpg|Early, hacker-geared motto ''Move Fast and Break Things''... File:Mark Zuckerberg on stage at Facebook's F8 Conference (14865414827).jpg|...to new motto ''Move Fast with stable Infra'' </gallery> F8 2014 was announced on March 8, 2014 by Facebook representative Ilya Sukhar that the F8 event would return on April 30.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/digits/2014/03/08/facebook-to-hold-f8-developer-conference-on-april-30/ |title=Facebook to Hold F8 Developer Conference on April 30 |publisher=Wall Street Journal |date= |accessdate=November 3, 2014}}</ref>
The conference was focused on Facebook's strategy to become a 'cross-platform platform'.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/05/02/f8/ |title=Everything Facebook Launched At f8 And Why |publisher=TechCrunch |date= |accessdate=June 3, 2014}}</ref>
Here is a list of the main topics:
* Audience Network * Autofill With Facebook * Anonymous Login * Removing The Ability To Pull Friends' Data * Granular Mobile Privacy Permissions * 2-Year Core API Stability Guarantee * Graph API 2.0 * FbStart * Mobile Like Button * Send to Mobile * Message Dialog * AppLinks * Visualization APIs For Media * Pricing changes * Analytics and Offline Storage * Internet.org Innovation Lab * DisplayNode
==2015== [[File:Mark Zuckerberg on stage at Facebook's F8 Developers Conference 2015 (16908770206).jpg|thumb|Users numbers updated for Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp, Messenger, and Groups at F8 2015]] The 2015 F8 conference was held on March 25, 2015 at the [[Fort Mason Center]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://venturebeat.com/2015/03/25/everything-facebook-announced-today-during-its-f8-developer-conference/|title=Everything Facebook announced during its F8 developer conference|last=Weber|first=Harrison|date=March 25, 2015|work=[[VentureBeat]]|access-date=May 2, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>
==2016== The 2016 F8 conference was held on April 12 and 13, 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thenextweb.com/facebook/2016/04/14/everything-facebook-announced-f8-2016/|title=Everything Facebook announced at F8 2016|last=Garun|first=Natt|date=April 14, 2016|work=The Next Web|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref>
Announcements: Facebook Analytics adds push and in app notifications feature <ref>https://developers.facebook.com/blog/post/2016/04/12/facebook-analytics-for-apps-adds-push-notifications-deeper-insights/</ref>
==2017== The 2017 F8 conference was held from April 18, 2017 to April 19, 2017, at the [[San Jose Convention Center]] in San Jose, California.<ref>{{cite web|title=Facebook Developer Conference 2017|url=https://www.fbf8.com|accessdate=January 31, 2017}}</ref> Announcements included:<ref>{{cite news|url=https://venturebeat.com/2017/04/18/everything-facebook-announced-at-f8-2017/|title=Everything Facebook announced at F8 2017|first=Ken|last=Yeung|date=April 18, 2017|work=[[VentureBeat]]}}</ref> * Integrating the camera more into Facebook and Messenger, including more 360º features * New [[augmented reality]] platform, challenging [[Snapchat]] * [[Facebook Messenger]]: chat extensions including [[Spotify]], [[Apple Music]], and [[Aeromexico]] - which are called up by the user but do not chat in groups; improved discovery, further integration of [[M (virtual assistant)|M]] [[virtual assistant (artificial intelligence)|[virtual assistant]] * [[Virtual reality]] hangout app for [[Oculus Rift]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/4/18/15332658/facebook-spaces-virtual-reality-oculus-rift-f8-conference-2017|title=Facebook’s bold and bizarre VR hangout app is now available for the Oculus Rift|last=Statt|first=Nick|date=April 18, 2017|work=The Verge|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> * [[Deep learning]] framework [[Caffe2]] * New 360º surround cameras * Helicopters that provide internet via fiber optic cable * Building 8 project aiming to allow people to type straight from their brain and hear through their skin<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com.au/facebooks-building-8-working-on-brain-computer-communication-platform-2017-1|title=Facebook's mysterious hardware division is working on tech to read brain waves that could let users send thoughts to each other|last=Heath|first=Alex|date=January 12, 2017|work=Business Insider Australia|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref>
==2018== The 2018 F8 conference was held from May 1, 2018 to May 2, 2018, at the [[McEnery Convention Center]] in San Jose, California.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/f8-2018-day-1-everything-facebook-announced/|title=F8 2018, day 1: Everything Facebook just announced|last=Falcone|first=John|date=May 1, 2018|work=CNET|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> At the conference, Facebook announced the creation of their own online dating service. Shares in the dating business [[Match Group]] fell by 22% after the announcement.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-43965204|title=Facebook F8: Zuckerberg's dating service takes on Tinder|work=[[BBC News]]|date=May 2, 2018|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref>

'''Hock burns''' are marks found on the upper joints of [[chickens]] and other [[birds]] raised on broiler [[farms]]. These marks are where the [[ammonia]] from the waste of other birds has burned through the skin of the leg, leaving a mark. Many meat processors now remove these marks as they discourage customers. Hock burn normally does not surpass 15% of a flock, according to poultry industry standards, but independent studies have found incidents of hock burn more common.<ref>[http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/s/167/167066_welfare_plea_over_supermarket_chickens.html Welfare plea over supermarket chickens.] ''Manchester Evening News.'' 25 July 2005.</ref> Researchers in Britain found that hock burn could be identified in 82% of chickens sold in supermarkets.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Broom|first1=DM|last2=Reefmann|first2=N|title=Chicken welfare as indicated by lesions on carcases in supermarkets|journal=British Poultry Science|date=August 2005|volume=46|issue=4|pages=407–14|doi=10.1080/00071660500181149|pmid=16268097}}</ref>

{{good article}} {{lowercase}} [[File:Msn iloo.jpg|thumb|alt=A 3D diagram of the proposed iLoo showing a blue, cuboid-shaped toilet cubical with a lavatory situated to the right. A computer keyboard and plasma screen are positioned opposite the toilet bowl, and a sink is in the centre. On top of the cubical is a wireless aerial with demonstrative waves emanating from it. Microsoft's MSN branding is in the left-hand corner of the diagram. |The iLoo as depicted by MSN UK and distributed by news providers]] The '''iLoo''' (short for '''[[Internet]] [[toilet|loo]]''') was a cancelled [[Microsoft]] project to develop a [[Wi-Fi]] [[Internet]]-enabled [[portable toilet]]. The iLoo, which was to debut at British summer festivals, was described as being a [[portable toilet]] with wireless broadband Internet, an adjustable plasma screen, a membrane wireless keyboard, a six-channel speaker system, and toilet paper embossed with popular [[URL|web site addresses]]. The iLoo was also to have an extra screen and keyboard on the outside, and was to be guarded. It was intended as the next in a series of successful initiatives by MSN UK which sought to introduce the internet in unusual locations, including MSN Street, MSN Park Bench and MSN Deckchair.
The project was announced by [[MSN|MSN UK]] on April 30, 2003, and was widely ridiculed before being declared a hoax by Microsoft on May 12. On May 13, another Microsoft press release stated that although the project had not been a hoax, it had been cancelled because it would do little to promote the MSN brand. There has since been speculation as to whether the project was cancelled for fear of being sued by Andrew Cubitt, who had invented the similarly named product "i-Loo". The iLoo was described as a public relations "debacle" by ''Online Journalism Review''.<ref name="ojr"/>
==Description== The iLoo was designed to be a [[Wi-Fi]] [[Internet]]-enabled [[portable toilet]] that would allow users to surf the internet while using the loo.<ref name="apr30pr"/> Internally, the facility would have a broadband connection via wireless [[802.11b]], a wireless waterproof keyboard, a swivel [[plasma screen]] running [[Windows XP Professional]], a 6-channel surround-sound system beneath the sink, toilet paper embossed with popular URLs, and a suction toilet.<ref name="apr30pr"/><ref name="cnetpotty">{{cite news |title=Sit and surf: MSN UK tests portable potty|url=http://news.cnet.com/2100-1041_3-999509.html |first=Joe |last=Wilcox |date=May 2, 2003 |publisher=CNET |accessdate=March 3, 2011}}</ref> Externally, the facility would feature an MSN logo and have a "[[Hotmail]] station" with an additional plasma screen and keyboard for waiting consumers.<ref name="cnetpotty"/> A security guard was to be stationed near the unit to ensure that it was being properly used and to prevent the unit from being stolen.<ref name="cnetpotty"/> The iLoo was to debut "at a majority of the summer season festivals".<ref name="apr30pr"/> The iLoo was to be deployed only in Britain.<ref>{{cite news|title=Doing the loo log on |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/334224561.html?FMT=ABS|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=May 8, 2003}} {{subscription}}</ref>
==Public relations timeline== {|class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 85%; background:#c6dbf7; color:black; width:25em; max-width: 25%;" cellspacing="5" |style="text-align: left;"|The internet's so much a part of everyday life now that surfing on the loo was the next natural step. People used to reach for a book or mag when they were on the loo but now they'll be logging on! It's exciting to think that the smallest room can now be the gateway to the massive virtual world. |- |style="text-align: left;"|—Tracy Blacher, Marketing manager of [[MSN]] in April 30 Press Release<ref name="apr30pr"/> |} The project was announced on April 30, 2003 in press release by [[MSN]] UK, MSN's British subsidiary, as part of a "series of MSN.co.uk initiatives which look at the changing nature of how we use the web as it constantly evolves".<ref name="apr30pr">{{cite press release |title=MSN Launches World's First 'Internet Loo':New WWW.C Offers Convenience Surfing Relief to Festival-goers this Summer |url=http://www.microsoft.com/uk/press/content/presscentre/releases/2003/05/PR03050.asp |publisher=Microsoft |date=April 30, 2003 |accessdate=March 1, 2011 |archivedate=May 11, 2003 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030511170309/http://www.microsoft.com/uk/press/content/presscentre/releases/2003/05/PR03050.asp}}</ref> The press release stated that:
{{quote|The UK's most popular website msn.co.uk is creating the world's first 'Internet Loo'. The iLoo will be mobile and is part of MSN's mission to allow instant logging on 'anytime and any place'.
In time for the summer festival season, MSN is in the process of converting a portable loo to create a unique experience for surfers looking for an alternative to the bog-standard festival loo experience. Users will be able to sit down, undock a wireless keyboard and conveniently access the first ever [[water closet|WWW.C.]]<ref name="apr30pr"/>}}
The press release also stated that "MSN is also in talks with toilet paper manufacturers to produce special web paper for those in need of URL inspiration".<ref name="apr30pr"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Who needs an online outhouse?|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/marionstar/access/1822603141.html?FMT=ABS|date=May 13, 2003|work=Marion Star|location=Marion, Ohio|accessdate=2011-03-07}}</ref><ref name="the age"/> {|class="toccolours" style="float: left; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 85%; background:#FED149; color:black; width:25em; max-width: 25%;" cellspacing="5" |style="text-align: left;"|MSN is really working on building a prototype for the Summer festivals, perhaps Glastonbury ... This is very much a 'toe in the water' experiment to gauge interest so we'll have to see how it goes, although judging from response so far it's really captured people's imagination! |- |style="text-align: left;"|—Ben Philipson, Red Consultancy, in response to AP query<ref name="aphoax"/> |} News of the iLoo was widely circulated amongst [[mainstream media]].<ref group="A">The iLoo was covered by the ''[[Associated Press]]'', ''[[BBC]]'', ''[[CNET]]'', ''[[Herald Sun]]'', ''[[Reuters]]'', ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', ''[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]'', ''[[Seattle Times]]'', ''[[The Guardian]]'', ''[[USA Today]]'', ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'', and a number of other news providers. See [[iLoo#References|references]] and [[iLoo#Further reading|further reading]] for more examples of coverage.</ref> The story became the most-emailed story on [[Yahoo! News]] on May 1, 2003, being emailed over 4000 times.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Winston |first=Paul |date=May 12, 2003 |title=Plumbing the Net for the real news |journal=Business Insurance |volume=37 |issue=19 |pages=6 |accessdate=February 26, 2011 |url=http://goliath.ecnext.com/coms2/gi_0199-2919573/Plumbing-the-Net-for-the.html}}</ref><ref group="A">This is based on {{cite web |url=http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl%3Dindex2%26cid%3D964 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050526073311/http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=index2&cid=964 |archivedate=2005-05-26 |df= }} now {{cite web |url=https://news.yahoo.com/most-popular |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150614025637/http://news.yahoo.com/most-popular/ |archivedate=2015-06-14 |df= }} which is a service provided by [[Yahoo!]] to track the most popular stories.</ref> The iLoo was widely derided and press coverage subjected [[MSN]] and [[Microsoft]] to heavy criticism. On May 10, ''[[The Inquirer]]'' published a story in which Andrew Cubitt alleged that "Microsoft stole his iLoo idea" from his i-Loo invention.<ref name="inq1">{{cite news |title=Man claims Microsoft stole his iLoo idea: Nothing new under the seat |url=http://www.theinquirer.net/inquirer/news/1004997/man-claims-microsoft-stole-his-iloo-idea |first=Mike |last=Magee |date=May 10, 2003 |work=[[The Inquirer]] |publisher= Incisive Media |accessdate=February 28, 2011}}</ref> On May 12, Microsoft announced that the iLoo was a "hoax perpetrated by its British division" calling it an "April Fool's joke" and issued an apology for the confusion.<ref name="aphoax">{{cite news|title=Microsoft: Internet-ready toilet project a hoax |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/news/archive/2003/05/12/financial0014EDT0002.DTL |date=May 12, 2003 |agency=Associated Press |publisher=SFGate |accessdate=February 28, 2011 |archivedate=May 16, 2003 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030516220206/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fnews%2Farchive%2F2003%2F05%2F12%2Ffinancial0014EDT0002.DTL |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="cnetgag">{{Cite web|title=iLoo makes Microsoft gag|url=http://news.cnet.com/2100-1041_3-1001109.html|first=Michael |last=Kanellos |date=May 12, 2003 |accessdate=March 3, 2011 |publisher=CNET}}</ref> The [[Associated Press]], however, stated that they had previously received confirmation of the project from two of Microsoft's PR firms: [[Waggener Edstrom Worldwide]] and Red Consultancy.<ref name="aphoax"/> The ''[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]'' also stated that it received confirmation from Waggener Edstrom and was even provided with a schematic drawing.<ref>{{cite news|title=Microsoft: Internet potty just a hoax |url=http://www.seattlepi.com/business/121744_iloo13.html|date=May 13, 2003 |work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] |accessdate=March 3, 2011}}</ref> Furthermore, [[April Fools' Day|April Fools]] was almost a month before, and Microsoft had never before released a fake press release.<ref name="cnetgag"/>
On May 13, 2003, Microsoft retracted the denial, stating that the iLoo had been a legitimate demonstration project that was to be released in Britain for summer music festivals, but had been terminated by Microsoft executives in [[Redmond, Washington]] who believed the iLoo was inappropriate<ref name="comeclean"/><ref name="eweek buzz">{{cite journal |date=May 19, 2003|title=The Buzz |journal=EWeek |volume=20 |issue=20 |pages=21 |issn=1530-6283 |url=http://www.eweek.com/c/a/Midmarket/The-Buzz-May-19-2003/ |accessdate=February 26, 2011}}</ref> with the final decision made by MSN senior vice president David Cole. MSN product manager Lisa Gurry stated that the project "didn't really map to our global branding objectives".<ref name="comeclean"/><ref name="apnothoax">{{cite news|title=Oh, It's Not a Hoax: MS ILoo |url=https://www.wired.com/techbiz/media/news/2003/05/58836 |date=May 13, 2003 |agency=Associated Press |work=[[WIRED]] |accessdate=February 28, 2011}}</ref> Microsoft again apologized for the miscommunication stating "the confusion over the legitimacy of this effort was caused by people moving too quickly and who misspoke before gathering all of the relevant information".<ref name="GUARD1"/> Prior to the cancellation, an iLoo prototype was in the "early stages of construction".<ref name="apr30pr"/><ref name="sp2">{{cite news|title=Internet invades portable potties |url=http://www.seattlepi.com/business/120677_iloo06.html |first=Dan |last=Richman |date=May 6, 2003|work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] |accessdate=February 26, 2011}}</ref> MSN allows regional units to design their own marketing campaigns, and the UK division had developed a reputation for innovative campaigns, in this case involving British [[toilet humour]].<ref name="apnothoax"/><ref name="sp1">{{Cite news |title=On-again, off-again iLoo is off for good |url=http://www.seattlepi.com/business/121865_iloo14.html |first=Dan |last=Richman |date=May 14, 2003 |accessdate=February 26, 2011 |work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Microsoft says iLoo not a hoax, but project dead anyway|url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/news/2003-05-14-iloo-hoax-retract_x.htm| work=The Associated Press| publisher=[[USA Today]]| date=May 14, 2003 | accessdate=March 1, 2011}}</ref> The iLoo which was designed for the UK as part of a "tongue-in-cheek marketing initiative" was "intended to be the next in line of a number of clever initiatives in the UK involving introducing the internet in interesting locations, including [[MSN Street]], [[MSN internet park bench|MSN Park Bench]] and MSN Deckchair".<ref name="GUARD1">{{cite news |title=iLoo plans go down the tube |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2003/may/14/microsoft.comment?INTCMP=ILCNETTXT3487 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=March 3, 2011|first=Jane |last=Perrone |date=May 14, 2003 |location=London}}</ref> The previous initiatives were well received.<ref name="CalabreseBurgelman1999">{{cite book|author1=Andrew Calabrese|author2=Jean-Claude Burgelman|title=Communication, citizenship, and social policy: rethinking the limits of the welfare state|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7ID8rPb5VPAC&pg=PA212|accessdate=March 4, 2011|year=1999|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=978-0-8476-9108-1|pages=211–214}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Park bench goes online|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/1475654.stm|date=August 6, 2011|work=BBC|accessdate=March 1, 2011}}</ref> Microsoft stated that no employees were disciplined as a result of the debacle, although the company stated that it would conduct "internal discussions".<ref name="yesno">{{cite journal |last=Keefe |first=Lisa M. |date=December 8, 2003|title=Yes. No. Yes ... but |journal=Marketing News |volume=37 |issue=25 |pages=21 |issn=0025-3790}}</ref>
==Reaction== {|class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 85%; background:#86C3C3; color:black; width:25em; max-width: 25%;" cellspacing="5" |style="text-align: left;"|Reading in the loo, or the bog, is a traditional English pastime. We've all seen the magazine racks, loo paper with jokes and cartoons on the walls in toilets up and down the land. You've got to hand it to the creative—and uniquely English—minds at Microsoft. |- |style="text-align: left;"|—Jeremy Davies, market researcher from Context<ref name="cnetpotty"/> |} Although the product was not publicly released, many questioned whether "Microsoft had lost its senses" and the product was widely derided.<ref name="Internet appliance images">{{Cite web|title=Internet appliance images|url=http://images.yourdictionary.com/internet-appliance|accessdate=February 26, 2011|work=Computer Desktop Encyclopedia|publisher=LoveToKnow, Corp.|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110319052227/http://images.yourdictionary.com/internet-appliance|archive-date=2011-03-19|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Skip to iLoo |url=http://blogcritics.org/scitech/article/skip-to-iloo/ |first=Eric |last=Olsen|date=May 14, 2003 |accessdate= February 26, 2011 |publisher=Blog Critics}}</ref> Critics contended that the product was a waste of money and doomed to fail.<ref name="eweek buzz"/> Concerns were raised about how the iLoo would serve to extend waiting lines,<ref name="the age">{{cite news|title=If loo queues are bad, just try going online |url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/05/06/1051987703123.html |first=Lowe |last=Sue |date=May 7, 2003|work=The Age |accessdate= March 1, 2011 |location=Melbourne}}</ref> how hygienic it would be to share keyboards in a public loo, and what would happen if the keyboard were to be urinated upon.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Fowler |first=Dennis |date=September 2003|title=Something old and something new|journal=NetWorker|volume=7|issue=3|pages=5 |doi=10.1145/940830.940836}}</ref><ref name="sp3">{{cite news|url=https://theinsiderknowledge.blogspot.com/2004/10/the-insider-not-all-readers-clamoring.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027192444/https://theinsiderknowledge.blogspot.com/2004/10/the-insider-not-all-readers-clamoring.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=October 27, 2016|title=The Insider: Not all readers clamoring for a chance to potty-surf|last=|first=|date=May 10, 2004|work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]|via=|accessdate=February 26, 2011}}</ref> Critics also questioned whether users would spend enough time in the loo to make use of the internet facilities, noting that "most port-a-potty users stay only long enough to relieve themselves without having to inhale."<ref>{{cite news |title=Www.dumbidea.com |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/648422031.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT |date=June 14, 2003 |publisher=[[The Toronto Star]] |accessdate=February 28, 2011}} {{subscription}}</ref>
The iLoo, given its toiletry-related nature, subjected MSN and Microsoft to puns and jokes especially since Microsoft's marketing slogan at the time was "[[where do you want to go today?]]" with the PC being dubbed Pee-C.<ref name="ojr">{{Cite web |title=Media Cred in Toilet with Blair, iLoo Debacles |url=http://www.ojr.org/ojr/glaser/1052982028.php|first=Mark |last=Glaser |date=May 15, 2003 |accessdate=February 26, 2011 |work=Online Journalism Review}}</ref><ref name="yesno"/><ref name="sp3"/><ref name=Greene1>{{cite news|last=Greene|first=Jay|title=No Windows-Wiper Jokes, Please|url=http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/03_22/c3835012_mz003.htm#B3835020|accessdate=27 April 2012|newspaper=BusinessWeek|date=June 2, 2003}}</ref><ref name="mt">{{cite journal |date=July 2003 |title=Brain Food: Words-worth – Brand extension |journal=Management Today |pages=22 |accessdate=February 26, 2011 |issn=0025-1925 |url=http://www.managementtoday.co.uk/news/412473/BRAIN-FOOD-Words-worth---Brand-extension/}}</ref> The ''[[Herald Sun]]'' wrote that the "iLoo is, unquestionably, very good news – mainly to journalists with a bottomless pit of laboured bum jokes" while the ''[[Seattle Times]]'' wrote "now the company has a credibility problem as well as a red face."<ref name="comeclean">{{cite news |title=Microsoft comes clean on iLoo |url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20030514&slug=iloo14 |first=Brier |last=Dudley |work= The Seattle Times |date= May 14, 2003 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Easy on the download|first=Terry |last=Brown|date=May 17, 2003|work=[[Herald Sun]]|location=Melbourne}}</ref> Other newspapers issued humorous headlines: ''Microsoft technology headed for toilet'' from the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'',<ref>{{cite news |title=Microsoft technology headed for toilet |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2003/05/06/BU135929.DTL |date= May 6, 2003 |publisher=Hearst Newspapers |work=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=February 26, 2011}}</ref> ''Toilet mixes zeroes with ones and twos'' from the ''[[Washington Post]]'',<ref>{{cite news|title=Toilet mixes zeroes with ones and twos |url=http://goliath.ecnext.com/coms2/gi_0199-2791231/Toilet-mixes-zeroes-with-ones.html|first=Tim |last=Lemke|date=May 7, 2003|work=The Washington Times|accessdate=2011-03-04}} {{subscription}}</ref> and ''Microsoft's Gone Potty'' from ''[[The Daily Mirror]]''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Microsoft's Gone Potty |first=Amy |last=Vickers |date=May 2, 2003 |work=The Daily Mirror |location= London }}</ref>
The product has since been studied as an example of a public relations disaster and an example of an [[internet hoax]].<ref name="cnn1">{{cite news |title=Winner, Dumbest Moment, Product Development: Microsoft: In the crapper? |url=http://money.cnn.com/galleries/2007/biz2/0701/gallery.dumbest_2003/4.html |first1=Adam |last1=Horowitz |date=Jan 1, 2004 |first2=Mark |last2=Athitakis |first3=Mark |last3= Lasswell |first4=Owen |last4=Thomas |agency=[[Business 2.0]] |work=101 Dumbest moments in Business:Dumbest moments of 2003 |publisher=CNN |accessdate= February 26, 2011}}</ref><ref name="cnet Business |accessdate=February 27, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|date=May 14, 2003|title=Microsoft 'Net loo canned |journal=Toronto Star|location=Canada|issn=0319-0781}}</ref>
The iLoo's negative publicity drowned out the launch of MSN Radio Plus on May 12, 2003.<ref>{{cite news |title=Nothing but 'Net – The doctor is online |date=June 2, 2003 |series=Sci-Tech |location=Fort Wayne, IN |work=The Journal Gazette |page=6D |quote=Microsoft Corp. might have gotten decent publicity over a new paid Internet radio service, but instead it found itself drowned in a wave of ridicule over its on-again, off-again Internet toilet.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Microsoft sets MSN radio initiative |url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/microsoft-sets-msn-online-radio-initiative |date=May 12, 2003 |publisher=MarketWatch |accessdate=February 28, 2011}}</ref> It has since inspired a number of spoofs.<ref name="museumofhoaxes">{{Cite web|title=The Microsoft iLoo |url=http://www.museumofhoaxes.com/hoax/archive/permalink/the_microsoft_iloo/ |date=April 30, 2003 |accessdate=February 26, 2011 |publisher=The Museum of Hoaxes}}</ref>
==i-Loo controversy== After reading an article about the iLoo, '''Andrew Cubitt''', inventor of the similarly named i-Loo, wrote to ''[[The Inquirer]]'' stating that iLoo "sounds remarkably similar ... it now seems that the clever people at Microsoft have cottoned onto the idea and even call it the i-Loo, the same as mine!"<ref name="inq1"/> Cubitt went on to say that "mine did everything that the Microsoft one is meant to do, but additionally printed information on toilet paper and didn't use a keyboard for the interface due to hygiene reasons".<ref name="Inquire2"/> The i-Loo was prototyped by Cubitt as part of his thesis for his 2001 university degree in Product Design and Engineering at [[Brunel University]]. In an interview with ''The Inquirer'', he noted "As it was designed at the university, they own the partial rights to the product so they will be watching the Microsoft 'invention' very closely."<ref name="Inquire2">{{cite news|title=Did Microsoft "borrow" the iLoo concept?: Strange case of "Microsoft's" i-Loo continues |url=http://www.theinquirer.net/inquirer/news/1049073/did-microsoft-borrow-the-iloo-concept |first=Adamson |last=Rust |date= May 12, 2003 |work=[[The Inquirer]] |publisher= Incisive Media |accessdate= February 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Computer chip in the old chopping block |url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/04/19/1050172799465.html |work=The Sun-Herald |location=Sydney |accessdate= February 28, 2011 |date=April 20, 2003}}</ref>
Microsoft never formally commented on Cubitt's allegations and instead initially stated the iLoo was an April's fool joke.<ref name="Inquirefool">{{cite news |title=Microsoft's iLoo was April Fool's joke |url=http://www.theinquirer.net/inquirer/news/1041723/microsofts--iloo-was-april-fools--joke |first=Mike |last=Magee|date= May 13, 2003 |work=[[The Inquirer]] |publisher= Incisive Media |accessdate=February 28, 2011}}</ref> As a result, Cubitt questioned whether this was "a very calculated ploy to destroy competition in its early stages, or is admitting they don't even know what time of the month it is less embarrassing and ridding them of a potentially expensive situation!"<ref name="Inquirefool"/><ref name="Inquire4">{{cite news|title=Real iLoo inventor hits out at Microsoft "slur": Letter Inventor's idea down the pan |url=http://www.theinquirer.net/inquirer/news/1013936/real-iloo-inventor-hits-out-at-microsoft-slur |first=Andrew |last=Cubitt |date= May 13, 2003 |work=[[The Inquirer]] |publisher= Incisive Media |accessdate=February 28, 2011}}</ref> Cubitt went on to state that "as they have now discredited my idea as a joke, I will never be able to produce the idea" and as such was "consulting my law books now on defamatory statements".<ref name="Inquire4"/> Neither Cubitt, nor [[Brunel University]] have taken public legal action against Microsoft pertaining to the i-Loo.
The i-Loo was described as:
<blockquote>The i-Loo internet toilet roll browser is a novel and unique product designed to make best use of the time you spend on the loo! The product allows you to search the internet whilst sitting on the toilet and print out any web pages you are interested in on your toilet paper. i-Loo brings a whole new meaning to the word downloading. The unit is fixed in front of a toilet on the cubical [''sic''] wall. The product provides up to date information about new products, daily news and lottery results through an easy to navigate software package. Normal operation of the toilet and paper dispenser is evident.<ref name="i-loo">{{Cite web |title=i-loo |url=http://www.nmabathrooms.co.uk/info/iloo.htm |first=Andrew |last=Cubitt |accessdate=February 28, 2011 |publisher=mabathrooms.co.uk |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111116101630/http://www.nmabathrooms.co.uk/info/iloo.htm |archive-date=2011-11-16 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref></blockquote>
The i-Loo internet toilet roll browser was featured at the 2003 ''Daily Mail'' Ideal Home Show as part of the Future Concepts exhibition in [[Earls Court]], London, where it was nominated for the MFI Bright Sparks 2003 awards.<ref name="i-loo"/><ref>{{cite news |title=Inventor rocked by MSN's iLoo hoax |url=http://www.webuser.co.uk/news/top-stories/379950/inventor-rocked-by-msn-s-iloo-hoax |first=Claire |last=Woffenden |date= May 13, 2003|publisher=[[Webuser]] |accessdate=February 28, 2011}} {{Dead link|date=April 2012|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Web goes down the toilet |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/2917739.stm |date=April 5, 2003 |publisher=BBC |accessdate=February 28, 2011}}</ref> The i-Loo, which was sponsored by [[Epson]] Printers, received significant press coverage, and was featured on [[GMTV]] as well as various radio shows.<ref name="i-loo"/><ref>{{cite news |title=City diary |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2003/apr/08/8 |first=Richard |last=Adams |date=April 8, 2003 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=February 28, 2011 |location=London}}</ref><ref name="timeoff">{{cite journal|last=Susan |first=Maushart|date=May 3, 2003 |title=Time off in loo|journal=Australian Magazine|pages=42|quote=The release (if that's the right word for it) of Cubitt's Internet toilet roll browser - a cubicle-mounted unit providing up-to-the-minute news and information that can be printed off on a standard toilet roll - made a huge media splash. And no wonder.}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|date=April 12, 2003|title=Science & Technology|journal=Weekend Australian |series=6 - NSW Country|pages=T13|quote=MEANWHILE, in London, high-tech attention was focused on the dunny when designer Andrew Cubitt revealed his internet toilet roll browser to the world at the Ideal Home Show. Those who can no longer stomach flicking through Gary Larson collections while on the loo will be able to turn to the device, which is mounted on the lavatory door, and can print out information on toilet paper.}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|date=April 10, 2003 |title=Web in the toilet.|publisher=Asia Africa Intelligence Wire|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-22935522_ITM|accessdate=March 7, 2011}}</ref>

{{Use British English|date=April 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{infobox music festival | music_festival_name = Infest Festival | image = Marsheaux 2008 Infest 2.jpg | caption = "The UK's Premier Festival of Alternative Electronic Music" | location = [[Bradford]], [[West Yorkshire]], England | years_active = 1998 to today | founders = 1998 "Black Lobster Promotions", 1999 "Slag Industries", from 2000 until today "Terminal Productions" | dates = Annually in August, usually Summer [[Bank Holiday]] weekend | genre = [[Industrial music]], [[Electronic body music]], [[Synthpop]], [[Futurepop]], [[Rhythmic noise]], [[Gothic rock]], [[Deathrock]], [[Darkwave]] and related genres | website = http://infestuk.com/ }} '''Infest''' (originally stylised as '''InFest''') is an annual three-day music festival held at the [[University of Bradford Union]] in the United Kingdom, featuring [[alternative electronic]] music acts from genres including [[industrial music|industrial]], [[electronic body music|EBM]], [[futurepop]], [[synthpop]] and [[power noise]]. The event usually takes place on the August [[bank holiday]] weekend.
==History== ===Background=== InFest was born in early 1998 through the efforts of three students of the [[University of Bradford]] - Gareth 'Gadge' Harvey, Chris 'Crusty' Molyneux, and Max 'Maxi Slag' - and the [[University of Bradford Union|Students' Union]] Entertainments Manager, Floyd Peltier. The concept of the festival was originally envisioned as a one-day event for local [[Gothic rock|goth]] bands in [[West Yorkshire]], but the crew were able to also onboard much bigger acts, such as [[gothic rock|gothic]]/[[deathrock]] band [[Alien Sex Fiend]]. The student organisers were already fans of the [[Whitby Gothic Weekend]] and took the idea for Infest to the [[Whitby]] festival-goers and traders to gauge how popular the show might be. The response was positive and the first Infest festival was confirmed as 14 and 15 August 1998.
The following year (1999), the festival paid more attention towards the electronic side of the goth and industrial scene by booking [[Apoptygma Berzerk]] for their first UK show.
===Reinvention=== By 2000, the University of Bradford's Students' Union felt that they couldn't carry the costs of the festival any longer. However, an [[independent music|independent]] goth/industrial [[promoter (entertainment)|promoter]] and DJ named Mark 'Gus' Guy (former drummer with the Indie band [[Kerosene (band)|Kerosene]]), who had been advising Molyneux during the show's early years, stepped in to fill the void. As a result of the heavy involvement with Guy and his [[Terminal Productions]] company, Infest took the form it is recognised as today: the festival's theme has moved from goth/industrial [[crossover (music)|crossover]] to alternative electronic, with a greater emphasis on [[power noise]], futurepop, [[synthpop]] and [[electronic body music]]. However, occasionally more [[darkwave]]-style [[Gothic rock|goth]] bands do still appear on the line-up.
The stylisation of the name had changed in 2003 to be "Infest", and from this time has grown significant international recognition. The show continues to provide a market for traders, which helps to bring the music and the lifestyle of the show's fans together. There is also a full festival program where [[nightclubs]], DJs, [[band (music)|bands]] and businesses can make their voices heard. Infest has been supported by a number of electronic [[record label]]s, notably [[Ant-Zen]], Hands Productions, now-defunct [[online]] music store [[Music Non Stop]], Storming the Base (part of the record label [[Artoffact Records]]). Support outside the scene has also come from software publisher [[Ableton]], and drink manufacturers [[Jägermeister]] and [[A.G._Barr|Barr]].
In July 2013, the festival organisers announced that "it is highly unlikely that there will be an Infest in 2014";<ref>{{cite web|title=Infest 2014, Official Infest Homepage|url=http://www.infestuk.com/infest-2014/|accessdate=29 July 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130907025935/http://www.infestuk.com/infest-2014/|archivedate=7 September 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> but following "an avalanche of messages of support" the organisers have decided to "throw caution to the wind and go ahead with Infest in 2014 (The reason for announcing that infest 2014 was highly unlikely was due to AltFest being proposed to occur a couple of weeks before Infest in 2014. In the end Altfest was canceled due to lack of ticket sales and financial insecurity for the viability of a new big festival that had no history on the alternative music scene)."<ref>{{cite web|title=Confirmed: Infest 2014 Will Go Ahead, Official Infest Homepage|url=http://www.infestuk.com/confirmed-infest-2014-will-go-ahead/|accessdate=9 September 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130909184011/http://www.infestuk.com/confirmed-infest-2014-will-go-ahead/|archivedate=9 September 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Today=== Today, Guy has a small team of people at his side, including Molyneux (the remaining member of the founding team), along with a crew team that includes volunteers.
The festival celebrated their 20th anniversary in 2018, adding an extra day that year for the occasion.

{{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = International Dance Day |type = International |longtype = |official_name = |nickname = |observedby = All [[Member states of the United Nations|UN Member States]] |date = April 29 |frequency = Annual |scheduling = same day each year |celebrations = |relatedto = }}
'''International Dance Day''' is a global celebration of dance, created by the Dance Committee of the [[International Theatre Institute]] (ITI), the main partner for the performing arts of [[UNESCO]]. The event takes place every year on 29th April, the anniversary of the birth of [[Jean-Georges Noverre]] (1727-1810), the creator of modern ballet. The day strives to encourage participation and education in dance through events and festivals held on the date all over the world. [[UNESCO]] formally recognize ITI to be the creators and organizers of the event<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.international-dance-day.org/pdfs/ADG_message_idd_2015.pdf|title=Dance Day|archivedate=2015-04-29|}}</ref>.
== About == Every year, since its creation in 1982, an outstanding dance personality is selected to write a message for International Dance Day. ITI also create a flagship event in a selected host city, at which there are dance performances, educational workshops, humanitarian projects and speeches made by ambassadors, dignitaries, dance personalities and the selected Message Author for that year <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.international-dance-day.org/internationaldanceday.html|title=Dance Day|archivedate=2018-03-14|}}</ref>.
The day is a celebration day for those who can see the value and importance of the art form [[dance]], and acts as a wake-up-call for governments, politicians and institutions which have not yet recognised its value to the people.
== Event == To mark International Dance Day each year, on the 29 April, the International Theatre Institute invites its members along with dancers, choreographers, dance students and enthusiasts to join them in a Gala Celebration.
The Gala Celebration takes place in a chosen host city decided on by the Executive Council of the International Theatre Institute – for instance in 2017 it was held in [[Shanghai]], [[China]], and in 2018 it will be held in [[Havana]], [[Cuba]] <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.international-dance-day.org/mainevent.html/|title=Main Event|date=March 13, 2017|website=International Dance Day|publisher=Futura Communications|access-date=March 13, 2018}}</ref>.
The programme of the Gala Event can vary, but usually consists of top-quality dance performances from around the world, student performances, keynote speeches, and a recital of the Message for that year’s event read, in person, by that years selected message author.
In [[Shanghai]] 2017 for instance<ref>{{cite web |website= shine.cn |url= https://www.shine.cn/archive/metro/International-dance-day-to-be-celebrated/shdaily.shtml |title= International Dance Day to be Celebrated in Shanghai |author= XU Wei |authorlink=XU Wei |date= April 21, 2017 |publisher= Shanghai Daily |access-date= March 13, 2018 }}</ref>, the event became a three-day celebration with greater emphasis on education through dance workshops and presentations led by an international cast of dance experts. The evenings were reserved for performances, the finale of which was the Gala Celebration. The Shanghai event also had a humanitarian aspect, with much of its focus being on celebrating the achievements of disabled dancers and encouraging disabled children to dance <ref>{{cite book|title=IDD Brochure|last=ITI|date=2017|authorlink=International Theatre Institute}}</ref>.
Beyond the Gala itself, ITI Centres across the globe are encouraged to mark the 29th April in their own country through special educational initiatives, humanitarian drives, dance performances and festivals<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.international-dance-day.org/celebratingdanceday.html|title=International Dance Day - International Theatre Institute ITI|website=www.international-dance-day.org|language=en|access-date=2018-03-20}}</ref>.
== Message Authors == To help publicise International Dance Day each year the International Theatre Institute selects an outstanding personality from the world of dance to be the Message Author for the event. In the message, it is hoped that the author can underline the relevance and power of dance. Past authors have included [[Trisha Brown]], [[Alicia Alonso]], and [[Merce Cunningham]].
As 2018 marked the 70th Anniversary of ITI, 5 Message Authors were selected for the 2018 event, one from each of the 5 [[UNESCO]] Regions. The 5 authors were; [[Georgette GEBARA]] ([[Lebanon]], [[Arab]] Countries), [[Salia SANOU]] ([[Burkina Faso]], [[Africa]]), [[Marianela BOAN]] ([[Cuba]], The [[Americas]]), [[Willy TSAO]] ([[China]], [[Asia-Pacific]]) and [[Ohad NAHARIN]] ([[Israel]], [[Europe]]).
List of past Message Authors<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.international-dance-day.org/pastmessageauthors.html|title=International Dance Day - International Theatre Institute ITI|website=www.international-dance-day.org|language=en|access-date=2018-03-20}}</ref>;
{| class="wikitable" |+ !Year !Message Author(s) !Nationality |- |2017 |[[Trisha Brown]] |[[United States|USA]] |- |2016 |[[Lemi Ponifasio]] |[[Samoa]] & [[New Zealand]] |- |2015 |[[Israel Galván]] |[[Spain|Spanish]] |- |2014 |[[Mourad Merzouki]] |[[French people|French]] |- |2013 |[[Lin Hwai-min]] |[[Chinese Taipei]] |- |2012 |[[Sidi Larbi Cherkaoui]] |[[Belgium]] |- |2011 |[[Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker]] |[[Belgium]] |- |2010 |[[Julio Bocca]] |[[Argentina]] |- |2009 |[[Akram Khan (dancer)]] |[[United Kingdom]] |- |2008 |[[Gladys Agulhas]] |[[South Africa]] |- |2007 |[[Sasha Waltz]] |[[Germany]] |- |2006 |[[Norodom Sihamoni]] |[[Cambodia]] |- |2005 |[[Miyako Yoshida]] |[[Japan]] |- |2004 |[[Stephen Page]] |[[Australia]] |- |2003 |[[Mats Ek]] |[[Sweden]] |- |2002 |[[Katherine Dunham]] |[[United States]] |- |2001 |[[William Forsythe (choreographer)]] |[[United States]] |- |2000 |[[Alicia Alonso]], [[Jiří Kylián]] & [[Cyrielle Lecueur]] |[[Cuba]], [[Russia]] & [[France]] |- |1999 |[[Mahmoud Reda]] |[[Egypt]] |- |1998 |[[Kazuo Ohno]] |[[Japan]] |- |1997 |[[Maurice Béjart]] |[[France]] |- |1996 |[[Maya Plisetskaya]] |[[Russia]] |- |1995 |[[Murray Lewis]] |[[United States]] |- |1994 |[[Dai Ailian]] |[[China]] & [[Trinidad and Tobago]] |- |1993 |[[Maguy Marin]] |[[France]] |- |1992 |[[Germaine Acogny]] |[[Benin]] and [[Senegal]] |- |1991 |[[Hans van Manen]] |[[Netherlands]] |- |1990 |[[Merce Cunningham]] |[[United States]] |- |1989 |[[Doris Laine]] |[[Finland]] |- |1988 |Robin Howard |[[United Kingdom]] |- |1987 |Dance Committee of ITI |International |- |1986 |[[Chetna Jalan]] |[[India]] |- |1985 |[[Robert Joffrey]] |[[United States]] |- |1984 |[[Yury Grigorovich]] |[[Russia]] |- |1983 |No Message Author |N/A |- |1982 |[[Henrik Neubauer]] |[[Slovenia]] |}
