The [[United States]] is widely considered to have the most extensive and sophisticated intelligence network of any nation in the world, with notable suborganizations including the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] and the [[National Security Agency]], amongst others. It has conducted numerous espionage operations against foreign countries, including both allies and rivals. This includes industrial espionage <ref name="Bloomberg">[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-09-08/u-s-government-spied-on-brazil-s-petrobras-globo-tv-reports.html "Snowden Documents Show U.S. Spied on Petrobras, Globo TV Reports "], Bloomberg, September 8, 2013</ref> and cyber espionage.<ref name="New York Times">[https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/23/world/asia/nsa-breached-chinese-servers-seen-as-spy-peril.html "N.S.A. Breached Chinese Servers Seen as Security Threat"], New York Times, March 22, 2014</ref> Through a combination of hacking and secret court orders against American technology companies, the United States has also employed [[mass surveillance]] of ordinary individuals, both American and foreign nationals alike.
Many of these operations have generated public criticism as being unethical; examples include the overthrow of foreign governments, [[CIA transnational human rights actions#Human experimentation|nonconsensual human experiments]], [[extraordinary rendition]], [[Torture and the United States|torture]], [[targeted killing]]s, [[assassination]]s, and the [[CIA transnational human rights actions#Police training|funding and training]] of militants who would go on to kill civilians and non-combatants.<ref name="Resolution 1507 2006">[http://assembly.coe.int/Main.asp?link=/Documents/AdoptedText/ta06/ERES1507.htm Resolution 1507 (2006).] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612123848/http://assembly.coe.int/Main.asp?link=%2FDocuments%2FAdoptedText%2Fta06%2FERES1507.htm |date=June 12, 2010 }} Alleged secret detentions and unlawful inter-state transfers of detainees involving Council of Europe member states</ref><ref name="WaPoJun22">{{cite news |first=Karen |last=DeYoung |authorlink=Karen DeYoung |author2=Walter Pincus |title=CIA to Air Decades of Its Dirty Laundry|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/06/21/AR2007062102434_pf.html |publisher=Washington Post |date=2007-06-22 |accessdate= 2007-06-22}}</ref><ref name="washingtonpost.com">{{Citation|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/11/01/AR2005110101644.html |publisher=Washington Post |title= CIA Holds Terror Suspects in Secret Prisons |date=2005-11-02 |accessdate=2007-02-19 | first=Dana | last=Priest}}</ref>
==Edward Snowden disclosures on global mass surveillance== {{main|Global surveillance disclosures (2013–present)}} A cache of [[top secret]] documents [[Leak (news)|leaked]] in 2013 by ex-NSA contractor [[Edward Snowden]], who obtained them while working for [[Booz Allen Hamilton]], one of the largest contractors for defense and intelligence in the United States.,<ref name="WP20130610Security">{{cite news|title=Who holds security clearances?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/who-holds-security-clearances/2013/06/10/983744e4-d232-11e2-a73e-826d299ff459_graphic.html|accessdate=February 12, 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=June 10, 2013}}</ref> revealed operational details about the U.S. [[National Security Agency]] (NSA) and its international partners' [[global surveillance]]<ref>{{cite news|last=[[Barton Gellman]]|title=Edward Snowden, after months of NSA revelations, says his mission's accomplished|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/edward-snowden-after-months-of-nsa-revelations-says-his-missions-accomplished/2013/12/23/49fc36de-6c1c-11e3-a523-fe73f0ff6b8d_story.html|date=December 24, 2013|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|accessdate=December 25, 2013|quote=Taken together, the revelations have brought to light a global surveillance system ... }}</ref> of foreign nationals and U.S. citizens. In addition to a trove of U.S. federal documents, Snowden's cache reportedly contains thousands of Australian, British and Canadian intelligence files that he had accessed via the exclusive "[[Five Eyes]]" network. In June 2013, the first of Snowden's documents were published simultaneously by ''[[The Washington Post]]'' and ''[[The Guardian]]'', attracting considerable public attention.<ref>{{cite web|last=Greenwald|first=Glenn|title=NSA collecting phone records of millions of Verizon customers daily|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/06/nsa-phone-records-verizon-court-order|work=The Guardian|accessdate=August 16, 2013|quote=Exclusive: Top secret court order requiring [[Verizon]] to hand over all call data shows scale of domestic surveillance under [[Barack Obama|Obama]]}}</ref> The disclosure continued throughout the entire year of 2013, and a significant portion of the full cache of the estimated 1.7 million documents<ref name=cache>{{cite news|title=Pentagon Says Snowden Took Most U.S. Secrets Ever: Rogers|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-01-09/pentagon-finds-snowden-took-1-7-million-files-rogers-says.html|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|accessdate=January 9, 2014|quote=The Pentagon concluded that Edward Snowden committed the biggest theft of U.S. secrets in history, downloading about 1.7 million intelligence files, including information that could put personnel in jeopardy, according to lawmakers.}}</ref> was later obtained and published by many other media outlets worldwide, most notably ''[[The New York Times]]'', the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]], the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]], ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' (Germany), ''[[O Globo]]'' (Brazil), ''[[Le Monde]]'' (France), ''[[L'espresso]]'' (Italy), ''[[NRC Handelsblad]]'' (the Netherlands), ''[[Dagbladet]]'' (Norway), ''[[El País]]'' (Spain), and [[Sveriges Television]] (Sweden).<ref>{{cite web|title=NSA Primary Sources|url=https://www.eff.org/nsa-spying/nsadocs|publisher=[[Electronic Frontier Foundation]]|accessdate=December 14, 2013}}</ref>
These media reports have shed light on the implications of several [[Secret treaty|secret treaties]] signed by members of the [[UKUSA Agreement|UKUSA community]] in their efforts to implement [[global surveillance]]. For example, ''Der Spiegel'' revealed how the German [[Bundesnachrichtendienst]] (BND) transfers "massive amounts of intercepted data to the NSA",<ref name="spiegelsendnsa">{{cite web|author1=Hubert Gude, Laura Poitras |author2=Marcel Rosenbach |lastauthoramp=yes |title=German intelligence Sends Massive Amounts of Data to the NSA|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/german-intelligence-sends-massive-amounts-of-data-to-the-nsa-a-914821.html|publisher=''[[Der Spiegel]]''|accessdate=December 14, 2013|date=August 5, 2013}}</ref> while Sveriges Television revealed the [[National Defence Radio Establishment (Sweden)|National Defence Radio Establishment]] (FRA) provided the NSA with data from its [[diplomatic cable|cable collection]], under a secret treaty signed in 1954 for bilateral cooperation on surveillance.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gunnar Rensfeldt|title=NSA "asking for" specific exchanges from FRA – Secret treaty since 1954|url=http://www.svt.se/ug/nsafra4|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=December 14, 2013 |quote=This document, dated April 18th of this year, clearly shows that the relation is very close indeed, seemingly growing even closer. 'NSA's relationship with the FRA, an extremely competent, technically innovative, and trusted Third Party partner, continues to grow. The FRA provided NSA with access to its cable collection in 2011'}}</ref> Other security and intelligence agencies involved in the practice of [[global surveillance]] include those in [[Australian Signals Directorate|Australia]] (ASD), [[Government Communications Headquarters|Britain]] (GCHQ), [[Communications Security Establishment Canada|Canada]] (CSEC), [[Politiets Efterretningstjeneste|Denmark]] (PET), [[Directorate-General for External Security|France]] (DGSE), [[Bundesnachrichtendienst|Germany]] (BND), [[Agenzia Informazioni e Sicurezza Esterna|Italy]] (AISE), [[Algemene Inlichtingen en Veiligheidsdienst|the Netherlands]] (AIVD), [[Norwegian Intelligence Service|Norway]] (NIS), [[Centro Nacional de Inteligencia|Spain]] (CNI), [[Swiss intelligence agencies|Switzerland]] (NDB), as well as [[Unit 8200|Israel]] (ISNU), which receives raw, unfiltered data of U.S. citizens that is shared by the NSA.<ref name="israelnsa1">{{cite news|title=NSA shares raw intelligence including Americans' data with Israel|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/sep/11/nsa-americans-personal-data-israel-documents|accessdate=September 14, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=September 11, 2013|author1=Glenn Greenwald, Laura Poitras |author2=Ewen MacAskill |lastauthoramp=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=Tim Leslie |author2=Mark Corcoran |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Explained: Australia's involvement with the NSA, the US spy agency at heart of global scandal|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-11-08/australian-nsa-involvement-explained/5079786|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=December 18, 2013}}</ref><ref name=gchqpartner>{{cite web|last=Julian Borger|title=GCHQ and European spy agencies worked together on mass surveillance|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/nov/01/gchq-europe-spy-agencies-mass-surveillance-snowden|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|accessdate=December 18, 2013}}</ref><ref name=cbcspy>{{cite news|author1=Greg Weston |author2=Glenn Greenwald |author3=Ryan Gallagher |title=Snowden document shows Canada set up spy posts for NSA|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/snowden-document-shows-canada-set-up-spy-posts-for-nsa-1.2456886|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=December 13, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Denmark is one of the NSA's '9-Eyes'|url=http://cphpost.dk/news/denmark-is-one-of-the-nsas-9-eyes.7611.html|publisher=''[[The Copenhagen Post]]''|accessdate=December 18, 2013}}</ref><ref name=frlemjac>{{cite web|last=Jacques Follorou|title=La France, précieux partenaire de l'espionnage de la NSA|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/technologies/article/2013/11/29/la-france-precieux-partenaire-de-l-espionnage-de-la-nsa_3522653_651865.html|publisher=''[[Le Monde]]''|accessdate=December 18, 2013|language=French}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Christian Fuchs, John Goetz und Frederik Obermaier|title=Verfassungsschutz beliefert NSA|url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/spionage-in-deutschland-verfassungsschutz-beliefert-nsa-1.1770672|publisher=''[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]]''|accessdate=December 18, 2013|language=German}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Kjetil Malkenes Hovland|title=Norway Monitored Phone Traffic and Shared Data With NSA|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/norway-monitored-phone-traffic-and-shared-data-with-nsa-1384861974 |publisher=''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''|accessdate=December 18, 2013}}</ref>
The disclosure provided impetus for the creation of [[social movement]]s against mass surveillance, such as [[Restore the Fourth]], and actions like [[Aftermath of the global surveillance disclosure#"Stop Watching Us" rally|Stop Watching Us]] and [[The Day We Fight Back]]. <!--[[Domestic spying program]]s in countries such as France, the UK, and India have also been exposed.--> On the legal front, the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] joined a [[coalition]] of diverse groups filing suit against the NSA. Several [[human rights organizations]] have urged the [[Presidency of Barack Obama#Personnel|Obama administration]] not to prosecute, but protect, "[[whistleblower]] Snowden": [[Amnesty International]], [[Human Rights Watch]], [[Transparency International]], and the [[Index on Censorship]], ''inter alia''.<ref>{{cite web|title=USA must not persecute whistleblower Edward Snowden|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/news/usa-must-not-persecute-whistleblower-edward-snowden-2013-07-02|publisher=[[Amnesty International]]|accessdate=August 16, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=US: Statement on Protection of Whistleblowers in Security Sector|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2013/06/18/us-statement-protection-whistleblowers-security-sector|publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]]|accessdate=August 16, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Transparency International Germany |title=Transparency International Germany: Whistleblower Prize 2013 for Edward Snowden |url=http://www.transparency.org/news/pressrelease/transparency_international_germany_whistleblower_prize_2013_for_edward_snow|publisher=[[Transparency International]]|accessdate=August 16, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=US needs to protect whistleblowers and journalists|url=http://www.indexoncensorship.org/2013/06/us-needs-to-protect-whistleblowers-and-journalists/|publisher=[[Index on Censorship]]|accessdate=August 16, 2013}}</ref>
==Cyber espionage==
Snowden's revelations confirmed that the [[United States]], together with [[Israel]], conducted [[Operation Olympic Games]], a covert and still [[black operation|unacknowledged]] campaign of sabotage by means of cyber disruption, directed at [[Iran]]ian [[Nuclear program of Iran|nuclear facilities]]. As reported, it is one of the first known uses of offensive [[Cyberwarfare|cyber weapons]].<ref name=sanger/> Started under the [[George W. Bush]] administration in 2006, Olympic Games was accelerated under President [[Barack Obama|Obama]], who heeded Bush's advice to continue cyber attacks on Iranian nuclear facility at [[Natanz]].<ref name=sanger/><ref name=sanger>{{cite news|last=Sanger|first=David|title=Obama Order Sped Up Wave of Cyberattacks Against Iran|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/01/world/middleeast/obama-ordered-wave-of-cyberattacks-against-iran.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=19 October 2012|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=1 June 2012}} President Barack Obama "secretly ordered increasingly sophisticated attacks on the computer systems that run Iran's main nuclear enrichment facilities, significantly expanding America's first sustained use of cyber weapons"</ref> Amongst other things, they created the computer worm [[Stuxnet]], which spread beyond Iran's nuclear facilities to the internet, causing collateral damage in other nations such as [[India]] and [[Indonesia]].
==Industrial espionage==
In 1994, United States trade officials were accompanied with CIA agents to various international locations such as [[London]] and [[Geneva]] to spy on Japanese auto executives and government officials during Japan-U.S. negotiations on automotive trade.<ref name="New York Times1"/>
An article in the New York Times<ref name="New York Times1">[https://www.nytimes.com/1995/10/15/world/emerging-role-for-the-cia-economic-spy.html "Emerging Role For the C.I.A.: Economic Spy"], New York Times, October 15, 1995</ref> wrote:
{{quote|Spying on allies for economic advantage is a crucial new assignment for the C.I.A. now that American foreign policy is focused on commercial interests abroad. President Clinton made economic intelligence a high priority of his Administration, specifically information to protect and defend American competitiveness, technology and financial security in a world where an economic crisis can spread across global markets in minutes.}}
==Targeted killings and assassinations==
In April 2010, U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] placed [[Anwar al-Awlaki]] on a list of people whom the U.S. [[Central Intelligence Agency]] was authorized to kill because of terrorist activities.<ref name="washingtonpost2"/><ref name="nytimes1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/07/world/middleeast/07yemen.html|title=U.S. Approves Targeted Killing of American Cleric|last=Shane|first=Scott|date=April 6, 2010|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=April 6, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100408031248/http://www.nytimes.com//2010//04//07//world//middleeast//07yemen.html| archivedate= April 8, 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="telegraph"/> The "[[targeted killing]]" of an American citizen was unprecedented. Al-Awlaki's father and [[civil rights]] groups challenged the order in court.<ref name="washingtonpost2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/04/06/AR2010040604121.html|title=Muslim cleric Aulaqi is 1st U.S. citizen on list of those CIA is allowed to kill|last=Miller|first=Greg|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=April 6, 2010|accessdate=April 9, 2010}}</ref><ref name="telegraph">{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/barackobama/7564581/Barack-Obama-orders-killing-of-US-cleric-Anwar-al-Awlaki.html|title=Barack Obama orders killing of US cleric Anwar al-Awlaki|first=Tom|last=Leonard|date=April 7, 2010|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=April 8, 2010|location=London|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100411042550/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/barackobama/7564581/Barack-Obama-orders-killing-of-US-cleric-Anwar-al-Awlaki.html|archivedate=April 11, 2010|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aclu.org/national-security/al-aulaqi-v-panetta|title=Al-Aulaqi v. Panetta; American Civil Liberties Union |publisher=Aclu|date=September 13, 2012|accessdate=October 23, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Perez">{{cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703296604576005391675065166 |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|first=Evan|last=Perez|title=Judge Dismisses Targeted-Killing Suit|date=December 8, 2010}}</ref> Al-Awlaki was believed to be in hiding in Southeast [[Yemen]] in the last years of his life.<ref name="www.msnbc.com">[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/39962939/ns/world_news-mideastn_africa "Yemen charges U.S.-born cleric with plot to kill foreigners"], Associated Press. November 2, 2010; retrieved November 2, 2010.</ref> The U.S. deployed [[unmanned aerial vehicle|unmanned aircraft]] (drones) in Yemen to search for and kill him,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/yemen/7663661/American-drones-deployed-to-target-Yemeni-terrorist.html|location=London|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|first1=Con|last1=Coughlin|first2=Philip|last2=Sherwell|title=American drones deployed to target Yemeni terrorist|date=May 2, 2010}}</ref> firing at and failing to kill him at least once,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/anwar-al-awlaki-targeted-us-drones-osama-bin/story?id=13549218|title=Anwar al-Awlaki Targeted By U.S. Drones After Osama Bin Laden Raid|publisher=ABC News|date=May 6, 2011|accessdate=September 30, 2011}}</ref> before succeeding in a fatal American drone attack in Yemen on September 30, 2011.<ref name="BBC death">{{cite news|title=Islamist cleric Anwar al-Awlaki 'killed in Yemen'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-15121879|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=September 30, 2011|date=September 30, 2011}}</ref> Two weeks later, al-Awlaki's 16-year-old son, [[Abdulrahman al-Awlaki]], a U.S. citizen who was born in [[Denver]], was killed by a [[CIA]]-led [[unmanned combat air vehicle|drone strike]] in Yemen.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/16/world/middleeast/yemeni-security-forces-fire-on-protesters-in-sana.html Kasinov, Laura, "Fatal Strikes Hit Yemen as Violence Escalates", ''The New York Times'', 15 October 2011]</ref><ref>Herridge, Catherine, "Obama Administration Pressed for Accountability After Americans Killed in Anti-Terror Airstrikes", Fox News, October 25, 2011 [http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/10/25/killing-anwar-al-awlaki-unexpected-precedent-for-obama-administration/#ixzz1br7DKnlM]</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/anwar-al-awlakis-family-speaks-out-against-his-sons-deaths/2011/10/17/gIQA8kFssL_story.html|work=The Washington Post|date=October 18, 2011| first=Thomas|last=Erdbrink|title=Anwar al-Awlaki's family speaks out against his son's death in airstrike}}</ref> Nasser al-Awlaki, Anwar's father, released an audio recording condemning the killings of his son and grandson as senseless murders.<ref name="articles.cnn.com">{{cite news|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-12-08/middleeast/world_meast_yemen-awlaki-father_1_imam-anwar-drone-strike-awlaki?_s=PM:MIDDLEEAST |work=CNN |title=Official: Drone attack kills Al-Awlaki's son in Yemen |date=October 15, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111220120446/http://articles.cnn.com/2011-12-08/middleeast/world_meast_yemen-awlaki-father_1_imam-anwar-drone-strike-awlaki?_s=PM%3AMIDDLEEAST |archivedate=December 20, 2011 |df= }}</ref> In June 2014, a previously classified [[memorandum]] issued by the [[United States Department of Justice]] was released, justifying al-Awlaki's death as a lawful act of war.<ref name = "2014Memo" >{{cite web | last = Lauter | first = David | url = http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-drone-memo-awlaki-20140623-story.html | title = Memo justifying drone killing of American Al Qaeda leader is released | date = June 23, 2014 | publisher = ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' }}</ref>
==Intelligence activity by location==
===Europe===
====France====
In 1993, the CIA's Paris station launched an economic espionage operation to gain an advantage in negotiations over the 1994 [[General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade]]. They attempted to use a female operative posing as a public relations director for a save-the-rain-forest foundation as a [[Honey trapping|honeypot trap]] to ensnare Henri Plagnol, an aide to French prime minister [[Édouard Balladur]]. However, Plagnol was warned by French counterintelligence officers who has seen through the plot and told him to play along. Over the course of two years, the French used Plagnol to turn the tables on the CIA, uncovering multiple CIA operatives and ultimately publicly expelling the CIA Paris station chief along with other key agents from the country.<ref name="New York Times1"/>
====Germany====
The CIA recruited over a dozen spies working in multiple German industries, including a [[double agent]] in German intelligence. These spies were uncovered in raids on the Ministry of Defense by German authorities in 2014. Angela Merkel, whose personal cellphone was tapped by the NSA, ordered the expulsion of CIA's Berlin station chief.<ref name="RT1">[http://rt.com/news/172460-cia-spies-germany-merkel-bild/ "Over a dozen CIA-recruited spies work in German ministries – report"], RT, July 13, 2014</ref>
===Middle East===
====Iran====
{{Main|1953 Iranian coup d'état}} {{See also|Tudeh Party|Iran hostage crisis}}
In 1953, the CIA worked with the [[United Kingdom]] to overthrow the democratically elected government of [[Iran]] led by [[Prime Minister of Iran|Prime Minister]] [[Mohammad Mossadegh]] who had attempted to [[nationalize]] Iran's petroleum industry, threatening the profits of the [[Anglo-Iranian Oil Company]], now known as [[BP]].<ref>''The New York Review of Books'', [http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/2012/aug/16/crass-and-consequential-error/ "A Crass and Consequential Error,"] reviewing the book ''Patriot of Persia: Muhammad Mossadegh and a Tragic Anglo-American Coup'' by [[Christopher de Bellaigue]], 16 August 2012.</ref> Declassified CIA documents show that Britain was fearful of Iran's plans to nationalize its oil industry and pressed the U.S. to mount a joint operation to depose the prime minister and install a [[puppet regime]].<ref name="NYTsr2000">{{Cite news | work = [[New York Times]] | title = Special Report: Secret History of the CIA in Iran | url = https://www.nytimes.com/library/world/mideast/041600iran-cia-index.html | year = 2000}}</ref> In 1951 the [[Majlis|Iranian parliament]] voted to nationalize the petroleum fields of the country.<ref name="NYTsr2000"/><ref>{{cite web| title=Country Studies: Iran| work=[[Library of Congress]] | url=http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/irtoc.html | accessdate=March 7, 2007}}</ref>
The coup was led by CIA operative [[Kermit Roosevelt, Jr.]] (grandson of President [[Theodore Roosevelt]]). With help from [[British intelligence]], the CIA planned, funded and implemented [[Operation Ajax]].<ref>[[National Security Archive]], cited in "[http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB126/index.htm National Security Archive] Muhammad Mosaddeq and the 1953 Coup in Iran", edited by Mark J. Gasiorowski and Malcolm Byrne, Syracuse University Press 2004.</ref> In the months before the coup, the UK and U.S. imposed a boycott of the country, exerted other political pressures, and conducted a massive covert propaganda campaign to create the environment necessary for the coup. The CIA hired Iranian [[agents provocateurs]] who posed as communists, harassed religious leaders and staged the bombing of one cleric's home to turn the Islamic religious community against the government. For the U.S. audience, the CIA hoped to plant articles in U.S. newspapers saying that [[Shah]] [[Mohammed Reza Pahlevi]]'s return to govern Iran resulted from a homegrown revolt against what was being represented to the U.S. public as a communist-leaning government. The CIA successfully used its contacts at the [[Associated Press]] to put on the newswire in the U.S. a statement from [[Tehran]] about royal decrees that the CIA itself had written.<ref name=NYTsr2000/>
The coup initially failed and the Shah fled the country. After four days of rioting, Shi'ite-sparked street protests backed by pro-Shah army units defeated Mossadeq's forces and the Shah returned to power.<ref name="Bayandor2010">{{cite book|last=Bayandor|first=Darioush|authorlink=Darioush Bayandor|title=Iran and the CIA: The Fall of Mosaddeq Revisited|date=April 2010|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-0-230-57927-9}}</ref>
The CIA subsequently used the apparent success of their Iranian coup project to bolster their image in American government circles. They expanded their reach into other countries, taking a greater portion of American intelligence assets based on their record in Iran.<ref name=Bayandor2010/>
In August 2013 the CIA admitted that it was involved in both the planning and the execution of the coup, including the bribing of Iranian politicians, security and army high-ranking officials, as well as pro-coup propaganda.<ref name="CIA19532013admission_rt">{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/usa/iran-coup-cia-operation-647/|title=CIA finally admits it masterminded Iran’s 1953 coup|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/aug/19/cia-admits-role-1953-iranian-coup|title=CIA admits role in 1953 Iranian coup|first1=Saeed Kamali|last1=Dehghan|first2=Richard|last2=Norton-Taylor|date=19 August 2013|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref> The CIA is quoted acknowledging the coup was carried out "under CIA direction" and "as an act of U.S. foreign policy, conceived and approved at the highest levels of government."<ref name="CIA19532013admission_cnn">{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/08/19/politics/cia-iran-1953-coup/index.html|title=In declassified document, CIA acknowledges role in 1953 Iran coup - CNNPolitics.com|first=By Dan Merica and Jason Hanna|last=CNN|publisher=}}</ref> The [[National Security Archive]] said it that while it "applauds the CIA's decision to make these materials available, today's posting shows clearly that these materials could have been safely declassified many years ago without risk of damage to [[national security]]."<ref name="CIA19532013admission_rt"/>
===Asia=== ''The New York Times'' reported in May 2017 that "the Chinese government systematically dismantled C.I.A. spying operations in the country starting in 2010, killing or imprisoning more than a dozen sources over two years and crippling intelligence gathering there for years afterward. Current and former American officials described the intelligence breach as one of the worst in decades."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/20/world/asia/china-cia-spies-espionage.html?nytmobile=0|title=Killing C.I.A. Informants, China Crippled U.S. Spying Operations|last=Mazzetti|first=Mark|last2=Goldman|first2=Adam|access-date=2017-05-20|last3=Schmidt|first3=Michael S.|last4=Apuzzo|first4=Matt}}</ref>

{{For|the legal trade of species|Wildlife trade}} {{refimprove|date=October 2018|Animal Trafficking|talk=y|small=n|Science=Animals}} [[File:Confiscated Wildlife Products at JFK Airport.jpg|thumb|right|Confiscated wildlife products at [[JFK Airport]]]] '''Wildlife smuggling''' or trafficking involves the illegal gathering, transportation, and distribution of animals and their derivatives. This can be done either internationally or domestically. Estimates of the money generated by wildlife smuggling vary, in part because of its illegal nature. "Wildlife smuggling is estimated at $7.8bn to $10bn a year, according to the U.S. State Department.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/e/oes/ecw/wlt/|title=Wildlife Trafficking|website=www.state.gov|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-01}}</ref> The U.S. State Department also lists wildlife trafficking as the third most valuable illicit commerce in the world."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/travel/wildlife-trafficking-149079896/|title=Wildlife Trafficking|work=Smithsonian|access-date=2018-10-01|language=en}}</ref>The illegal nature of such activities make determining the amount of money involved incredibly difficult. When considered with illegal timber and fisheries, wildlife trafficking is a major illegal trade along with [[narcotics]], human trafficking, and counterfeit products.<ref name="Transnational Crime in the Developing World">{{cite web|last1=Haken|first1=Jeremy|title=Transnational Crime in the Developing World|url=http://www.gfintegrity.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/gfi_transnational_crime_high-res.pdf|website=Global Financial Integrity|publisher=Global Financial Integrity|accessdate=2014-08-30}}</ref><ref name="World Wildlife Fund">{{cite web|last1=Dalberg Global Development Advisors|last2=World Wildlife Fund|title=Fighting Illicit Wildlife Trafficking: A consultation with governments|url=http://www.dalberg.com/documents/WWF_Wildlife_Trafficking.pdf|website=World Wildlife Fund|publisher=World Wildlife Fund|accessdate=August 30, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923212439/http://www.dalberg.com/documents/WWF_Wildlife_Trafficking.pdf|archive-date=2015-09-23|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
Products demanded by the trade include [[exotic pet]]s, food, [[traditional medicine]], clothing, and jewelry made from animals' tusks, fins, skins, shells, horns, and internal organs. Smuggled wildlife is an increasing global demand; it is estimated that the [[US]], [[China]], and the [[European Union]] are the places with the highest demand.<ref>{{Citation|last=Uhm|first=Daan P. van|title=Illegal Wildlife Trade to the EU and Harms to the World|date=2016-06-01|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/305441741_Illegal_Wildlife_Trade_to_the_EU_and_Harms_to_the_World|pages=43–66|isbn=9781472469625|access-date=2018-10-01}}</ref>
==Culture== At the core of the illegal wildlife trafficking is a strong and rapidly expanding demand for a variety of products around the world: [[bushmeat]]; ingredients for [[traditional Chinese medicine]]; [[exotic pets]]; jewelry, trinkets, and accessories such as chess sets; furs for uses ranging from coats to traditional costumes; and trophies. With the exception of bushmeat, which is used as a primary source of protein by some cultures, all of these uses of illegally obtained wildlife are trophies, driven by a desire to be seen as more affluent, adventurous, or successful than others.
In many parts of Africa, the main demand for illegal wildlife comes from the consumption of [[bushmeat]]. Wild animals are a preferred as a source of protein and [[primates]] are considered a delicacy. It is believed that up to 40,000 monkeys are killed and eventually consumed each year in Africa alone via smuggling. Many primates are killed by bushmeat hunters, who supply to markets all over Africa, Europe, and the United States.
Much of demand for rhinoceros horns, tiger bones, and other animal products arises out of the practice of traditional Chinese medicine, which uses these ingredients to treat fevers, gout, and other illnesses;<ref name="Rhino Horn and Poaching">{{cite web|title=Poaching for Rhino Horn|url=http://www.savetherhino.org/rhino_info/threats_to_rhino/poaching_for_traditional_chinese_medicine|website=Save the Rhino|publisher=Save the Rhino International|accessdate=September 4, 2014}}</ref> maintain good health and longevity; and enhance sexual potency. Traditional Chinese medicines are taken by hundreds of millions of people. For example, some practitioners drink an expensive liquid made from tiger bones to improve their circulation, treat arthritis, and strengthen the body, in general.<ref name="thedailybeast.com">{{cite news|last1=Hong|first1=Brendon|title=China Is Brewing Wine From Tiger Bones|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/07/22/china-is-brewing-wine-from-tiger-bones.html|accessdate=September 4, 2014|agency=The Daily Beast|publisher=IAC|date=July 22, 2014}}</ref> The sale of tiger bones and products made from them is an example of the confusion that can exist on the topic. The sale of bones was outlawed in China in 1993; however, a pilot program, established in 2005, allows the use of bones for captive-bred tigers.<ref name="thedailybeast.com"/> This can create a confusion in the minds of buyers as to whether the bones were legally obtained. Regardless, tiger wine cannot be sold legally in China, although advertisements for it ran on state television channel in 2011 and journalist attended an auction where tiger wine was offered for sale.<ref name="Journalist attends auction">{{cite web|last1=Watts|first1=Jonathan|title='It's really good stuff': undercover at a Chinese tiger bone wine auction|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/blog/2011/dec/06/china-tiger-bone-wine-auction|website=The Guardian Environmental Blog|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=September 2, 2014}}</ref> Many of the traditional Chinese medicines fail to cure anything, although the demand for them continues to expand greatly and to the detriment of wildlife.<ref name="Brookings">{{cite book|last1=Felab-Brown|first1=Vanda|title=The Disappearing Act: The Illicit Trade in Wildlife in Asia|date=June 2011|publisher=Brookings Institution|pages=43|url=http://www.brookings.edu/~/media/research/files/papers/2011/6/illegal%20wildlife%20trade%20felbabbrown/06_illegal_wildlife_trade_felbabbrown.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140104024836/http://www.brookings.edu/~/media/research/files/papers/2011/6/illegal%20wildlife%20trade%20felbabbrown/06_illegal_wildlife_trade_felbabbrown.pdf|archivedate=2014-01-04|df=}}</ref>
[[Exotic pets]] are animals desired by consumers and are rare or simply not easily available in the owner's region. Television shows and movies can make certain animals popular. While many of these animals can be obtained from legal sources, many animals are captured from their native environments, smuggled across national borders,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hajek|first1=Daniel|title=Lucrative Illegal Animal Trade Thrives In Southern California|url=https://www.npr.org/2014/04/05/299385928/lucrative-illegal-animal-trade-thrives-in-southern-california|website=NPR|publisher=National Public Radio|accessdate=2014-09-13}}</ref> and wind up in family homes, menageries, or roadside circuses.<ref name="Brookings"/> Reptiles, such as bearded dragons and geckos, and birds, such as scarlet macaws and certain falcons,<ref>{{cite book|last1=South|first1=Nigel|last2=Brisman|first2=Avi|title=Routledge international handbook of green criminology|date=2013|publisher=Routledge|location=Abingdon, Oxon|isbn=9780415678827|url=https://books.google.com/?id=XTiYAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA310&lpg=PA310&dq=TANYA+WYATT+ILLEGAL+FALCON#v=onepage&q=TANYA%20WYATT%20ILLEGAL%20FALCON&f=false}}</ref> make up the largest share of animals captured and sold. Exotic mammals including [[three-toed sloths]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Scriffen|first1=John|last2=Waterfield|first2=Alex|title=Hottest-Selling Animal in Colombia's Illegal Pet Trade: Sloths|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/hottest-selling-animal-colombias-illegal-exotic-pet-trade/story?id=19172620|website=ABC News|accessdate=September 13, 2014}}</ref> sugar gliders, prairie dogs, hedgehogs,<ref>{{cite web|title=Facts about the Exotic Pet Trade|url=http://www.animalplanet.com/tv-shows/fatal-attractions/lists/facts-exotic-pet-trade.htm|website=Animal Planet|accessdate=2014-09-13}}</ref> and other animals are kept as pets. "Birds are the most common contraband; the State Department estimates that two million to five million wild birds, from hummingbirds to parrots to harpy eagles, are traded illegally worldwide every year."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/travel/wildlife-trafficking-149079896/|title=Wildlife Trafficking|work=Smithsonian|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en}}</ref> [[Tigers]] are a popular pet. An estimated 5,000 to 7,000 tigers (2013) are kept in the United States. The range of numbers is due, in part, to the lack of required reporting in some areas. For comparison, less than 400 of these big cats are in U.S. zoos accredited by the Association of Zoos and Aquariums<ref>{{cite web|title=Dangerous Exotic Pets: Big Cats|url=http://www.humanesociety.org/issues/exotic_pets/facts/dangerous-exotic-pets-big-cats.html|website=Humane Society of the United States|publisher=Dangerous Exotic Pets: Big Cats|accessdate=September 13, 2014}}</ref> and 3,200 live in the wild.<ref>{{cite web|title=More Tigers in American Backyards than in the Wild|url=http://www.worldwildlife.org/stories/more-tigers-in-american-backyards-than-in-the-wild|website=World Wildlife Fund|publisher=World Wildlife Fund|accessdate=September 13, 2014}}</ref> Tropical fish, nonhuman primates, and other animals are also part of the illicit pet trade.<ref name="Brookings"/> The U.S. has very strong natural animal and plan laws. Ivory is the hardest thing to bring in the US.. You cannot buy pearls out of state and bring them in. Most of the countries that has animal laws uses the template of CITES. If any animal has outside animal parts coming in, the US will not import it. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.worldwildlife.org/pages/buyer-beware|title=Buyer Beware {{!}} Pages {{!}} WWF|website=World Wildlife Fund|language=en|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref>
{{See also|Tiger Bone Wine}}
==Impact==
===Economic=== Members of [[List of designated terrorist organizations|terrorist organizations]] and [[criminal organizations]] illicitly traffic in hundreds of millions of plants and animals to fund the purchase of weapons, finance civil conflicts, and launder money from illicit sources.<ref name="policechiefmagazine.org">{{cite journal|last1=Sellar|first1=John|title=International Illicit Trafficking in Wildlife|journal=Police Chief Magazine|date=June 2007|volume=74|issue=6|url=http://www.policechiefmagazine.org/magazine/index.cfm?fuseaction=print_display&article_id=1203&issue_id=62007|accessdate=September 1, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://site.d66.nl/gerbrandy/document/eu_action_plan_against_wildlife/f=/vj7iilz6wlmw.pdf|title=Gerben Jan Gerbrandy claiming that terrorist networks hunt wildlife for funding themselves|author=Zite Media B.V.|publisher=|accessdate=7 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="John Sellar discusses Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES)">{{cite web|last1=Neo|first1=Hui Min|title=Smuggling wildlife: From eggs in a bra to geckos in underwear|url=http://phys.org/news168697589.html|website=Physorg.org|accessdate=August 30, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Malymail online">{{cite news|title=Malaysia’s ‘Lizard King’ under probe for wildlife smuggling, report says |url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/malaysias-lizard-king-under-probe-for-wildlife-smuggling-report-says|accessdate=September 1, 2014|publisher=themalaymailonline.com|date=November 2, 2013|ref=}}</ref> These often transnational efforts require a funding and a network of poachers, processors, smugglers, sellers, and buyers.<ref name="policechiefmagazine.org"/> Well armed, highly organized poaching activities, such as the murderous 2012 attacks in [[Chad]] and the [[Republic of Congo]], have captured headlines.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gettleman|first1=Jeffrey|title=Rangers in Isolated Central Africa Uncover Grim Cost of Protecting Wildlife|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/01/world/africa/central-africas-wildlife-rangers-face-deadly-risks.html|accessdate=August 30, 2014|publisher=New York Times|date=December 31, 2012}}</ref> The appeal, in part, is the low risk of detection and punishment compared to drug trafficking.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/j/inl/rls/rm/2014/226421.htm |title=The Escalating International Wildlife Trafficking Crisis: Ecological, Economic, and National Security Issues |work= |accessdate=August 30, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Trex|first1=Ethan|title=The Ins & Outs of Exotic Animal Smuggling|journal=Mental Floss|date=January 27, 2010|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/23803/ins-outs-exotic-animal-smuggling|accessdate=August 31, 2014}}</ref> In addition, trafficking can reap significant profits for those leading such efforts.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sellar|first1=John|title=International Illicit Trafficking in Wildlife|journal=Police Chief Magazine|date=June 2007|volume=74|issue=6|url=http://www.policechiefmagazine.org/magazine/index.cfm?fuseaction=print_display&article_id=1203&issue_id=62007|accessdate=August 31, 2014}}</ref> For example, a single Ploughshare tortoise from Madagascar (there are only 400 estimated left in the wild) can fetch US $24,000.<ref name="Malymail online"/>
Elephant ivory, a commonly trafficked contraband, can sell for little in the source country and can fetch high prices in destination countries. Prices depend greatly on the source country and the product.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Begley|first1=Sharon|title=Big Business: Wildlife Trafficking|url=http://www.newsweek.com/big-business-wildlife-trafficking-83865|accessdate=August 30, 2014|publisher=Newsweek|date=March 1, 2008}}</ref> Ivory prices and demand have skyrocketed, making it a growing, lucrative market. Globally, illegal ivory trade activity in 2014 is more than double what it was in 2007.<ref name="urlInterior Announces Ban on Commercial Trade of Ivory as Part of Overall Effort to Combat Poaching, Wildlife Trafficking">{{cite web |url=http://www.doi.gov/news/pressreleases/interior-announces-ban-on-commercial-trade-of-ivory-as-part-of-overall-effort-to-combat-poaching-wildlife-trafficking.cfm |title=Interior Announces Ban on Commercial Trade of Ivory as Part of Overall Effort to Combat Poaching, Wildlife Trafficking |format= |work= |accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref> China is the largest importer of illegal ivory; the United States is second.<ref name="Board 2014">{{cite web|last=Board|first=The Editorial|title=Banning Ivory Sales in America|website=The New York Times|date=2014-02-18|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/18/opinion/banning-ivory-sales-in-america.html|accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref><ref name="Christy 2012">{{cite web|last=Christy|first=Bryan|title=Ivory Worship|website=Pictures, More From National Geographic Magazine|date=2012-09-14|url=http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2012/10/ivory/christy-text|accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref><ref name="Moore 2014">{{cite web|last=Moore|first=Malcolm|title=Ivory trade: Can China get tough on tusks?|website=Telegraph.co.uk|date=2014-02-13|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/10636306/Ivory-trade-Can-China-get-tough-on-tusks.html|accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref>"According to reports from wildlife organization Save the Elephants, the price for raw ivory in China was $2,100 per kilogram."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.havocscope.com/tag/wildlife-trafficking/|title=Wildlife Trafficking – Statistics on the Illegal Wildlife Trade|website=www.havocscope.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> Between 2010 and 2012, up to 33,000 elephants were poached and killed on average each year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.havocscope.com/tag/wildlife-trafficking/|title=Wildlife Trafficking – Statistics on the Illegal Wildlife Trade|website=www.havocscope.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> Wildlife smuggling presents an economic cost to the countries where it occurs, including lost tourism and development opportunities.<ref name="Friday 2014">{{cite web|author=Friday|title=Wildlife Trade News - Poaching and illegal wildlife trade threaten tourism and development options in Africa|website=TRAFFIC|date=2014-03-07|url=http://www.traffic.org/home/2014/3/7/poaching-and-illegal-wildlife-trade-threaten-tourism-and-dev.html|accessdate=2014-08-31}}</ref>
===Health=== The spread of animal-borne disease affects both human health as well as threatening indigenous wildlife and natural ecosystems. According to the United States [[Government Accountability Office]], nearly 75% of emerging diseases that reach humans come from animals. The link between wildlife trafficking and disease outbreak is questioned, although outbreaks of certain diseases have suspected links to smuggled animals.
====Diseases believe to have originated and spread by wildlife smuggling==== *'''[[SARS|SARS (severe acute respiratory syndrome)]]''' is caused by a virus and infects both humans and wildlife. Experts suspect that the SARS virus originated in the China due to contact between a [[civets]] (wildcats common in Chinese trade) and humans. *'''[[Avian flu|Avian flu (H5N1)]]''' is caused by a highly pathogenic virus. It can infect humans through contact with infected crested hawks<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Van Borm|first1=S|last2=Thomas|first2=I|last3=Hanquet|first3=G|last4=Lambrecht|first4=B|last5=Boschmans|first5=M|last6=Dupont|first6=G|last7=Decaestecker|first7=M|last8=Snacken|first8=R|last9=van den Berg|first9=T|title=Highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza virus in smuggled Thai eagles, Belgium|journal=Emerging Infectious Diseases|date=May 2005|volume=11|issue=5|pages=702–5|pmid=15890123|pmc=3320388|url=http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/11/5/pdfs/05-0211.pdf|accessdate=October 3, 2014|doi=10.3201/eid1105.050211}}</ref> and other wild birds, but can be transmitted by contact with poultry as well. *'''[[Monkeypox]]''' is an infectious disease found in Africa's wildlife that can spread to humans.
====Diseases linked to animal species that are targets of wildlife smuggling==== *'''[[Herpes B virus]]''' is a virus found among macaque monkeys that can be transmitted by bites or scratches to humans in extremely rare cases. If not treated soon after exposure, severe brain damage or death can follow infection.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Center for Disease Prevention and Control|title=B Virus (herpes B, monkey B virus, herpesvirus simiae, and herpesvirus B)|url=https://www.cdc.gov/herpesbvirus/|website=Center for Disease Prevention and Control|publisher=Center for Disease Prevention and Control|accessdate=September 16, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Rice|first1=Thomas|title=Mother and Daughter Sentenced to Jail for Smuggling Monkey from Thailand|url=http://www.fws.gov/news/ShowNews.cfm?ID=EF38B798-FE9C-34D7-FA635FBC6DE29EE1|accessdate=September 14, 2014|agency=U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service|publisher=Department of the Interior|date=April 28, 2009}}</ref> *'''[[Salmonella]]''' infection can cause diarrhea, fever, and abdominal cramps. Infections have been linked to contact with turtles,<ref>{{cite web|title=Salmonella|url=https://www.cdc.gov/salmonella/general/prevention.html|website=Centers for Disease Prevention and Control|accessdate=October 3, 2014}}</ref> bearded dragons and other reptiles.
===Environmental=== Wildlife smuggling directly affects the biodiversity of different ecosystems. Certain animals are in higher demand by smugglers, leading to a visible decline of these species in their native habitats. Wildlife smuggling may also cause the introduction of invasive and harmful species into an ecosystem, which can endanger indigenous wildlife.
==International control measures== {{see also|Wildlife Enforcement Monitoring System}}
===Coalition Against Wildlife Trafficking=== The Coalition Against Wildlife Trafficking (CAWT) was established in 2005 by the U.S. [[Department of State|State Department]] as a voluntary [[coalition]] of governments and organizations that aims to end the illegal trade of wildlife and wildlife products.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cawt-global.squarespace.com/|title=CAWT - About|website=cawt-global.squarespace.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-01}}</ref> CAWT currently includes six governments and thirteen international [[NGO]]s. Their means of action include raising public awareness to curb demand, strengthening international cross-border law enforcement to limit supply, and endeavoring to mobilize political support from upper echelons.
===Association of Southeast Asian Nations Wild Enforcement Network=== The [[Freeland Foundation]] and [[Traffic (conservation programme)|TRAFFIC Southeast Asia]] worked with the [[Thailand|Thai]] government and the [[ASEAN|Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN)]], to establish the ASEAN Wildlife Enforcement Network (ASEAN-WEN) in 2005.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://environment.asean.org/the-asean-wildlife-enforcement-network-asean-wen/|title=The ASEAN Wildlife Enforcement Network (ASEAN-WEN)|date=2012-11-21|work=ASEAN Cooperation on Environment|access-date=2018-10-01|language=en-US}}</ref> ASEAN-WEN oversees cross-border cooperation and aims to strengthen the collective law enforcement capacity of the ten ASEAN member countries. It is the largest regional wildlife law enforcement collaboration in the world and receives support from the [[United States Agency for International Development]].
===South Asian Enforcement Network=== The South Asian Enforcement Network (SAWEN) was created with the help of CAWT and TRAFFIC.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sawen.org/|title=WelcomeSouth Asia Wildlife Enforcement Network|website=South Asia Wildlife Enforcement Network|language=en|access-date=2018-10-01}}</ref> In 2008, South Asian environment ministers agreed to create SAWEN under the support of the [[South Asia Co-operative Environment Programme]]. The SAWEN countries include [[Afghanistan]], [[Bangladesh]], [[Bhutan]], [[India]], [[Maldives]], [[Nepal]], [[Pakistan]] and [[Sri Lanka]].
====Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species==== The [[CITES|Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES)]] directs its efforts at the supply side of wildlife smuggling.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cites.org/eng/disc/what.php|title=What is CITES? {{!}} CITES|website=www.cites.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-01}}</ref> It aims to end wildlife smuggling and to ensure that international trade does not threaten endangered species.
==By country==
===Australia=== International trade of [[Australia]]'s wildlife is regulated under Part 13A of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.environment.gov.au/epbc|title=Department of the Environment and Energy|website=Department of the Environment and Energy|language=en|access-date=2018-10-01}}</ref> The same act implements provisions of CITES and the UN Biodiversity Convention in relation to imports of threatened biodiversity and wildlife.
===Ecuador=== Latin America is vulnerable to wildlife smuggling because of its biodiversity. [[Ecuador]] is known for its biodiversity. In northern Ecuador, the Yasuní National Park and the surrounding Waorani Ethnic Reserve, which cover about 1,770 square miles, are home to around 4,000 species of plants; numerous animals, including the giant river otter; more than 400 fish species; and more than 500 species of birds.<ref>{{cite web|last1=USAID|last2=Wildlife Conservation Society|title=The Global Conservation Program Achievements and Lessons Learned from 10 Years of Support for Threats-based Conservation at a Landscape and Seascape Scale: Greater Yasuní-Napo Moist Forest Landscape Conservati on Area (Ecuador)|url=http://pdf.usaid.gov/pdf_docs/PDACP728.pdf |website=USAID|publisher=USAID and Wildlife Conservation Society|accessdate=August 31, 2014}}</ref> As a comparison, the United States is home to 900 species of birds. Commonly smuggled birds include the [[scarlet macaw]]; this colorful bird, with bright red, brilliant blue, yellow, and white feathers, is in high demand as a pet.<ref name="Wildlife Trafficking">{{cite journal|last1=Bergman|first1=Charles|title=Wildlife Trafficking|journal=Smithsonian|date=December 2009|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/people-places/wildlife-trafficking-149079896/?=&no-ist=&page=1|accessdate=August 31, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Scarlet Macaw">{{cite web|title=Scarlet Macaw (Ara macao)|url=http://www.rainforest-alliance.org/kids/species-profiles/macaw|website=Rainforest Alliance|accessdate=August 31, 2014}}</ref> Animals stolen in Latin America often end up in Europe, the United States, or [[Japan]]. Though there are laws against wildlife smuggling, the lack of resources causes conservation to be low in priority.
